It manages to wrap up all story lines of the previous movies in one grand finale, and does so very convincingly.

Yes, there are Ewoks - cute and cuddly bears that arguably served to broaden the Star Wars demographic - and in the middle the movie tends to slow down a bit. But the final hour is arguably the best piece of the entire saga, where Luke finally comes face to face with Darth Vader, the most recognizable villain in movie history.

Return of the Jedi did so many things right that people tend to overlook: it presented an incredible conclusion to the Darth Vader storyline (which went from slightly implausible in the "Empire Strikes Back" to very convincing here), an exciting opening at Jabba's Palace, a masterful performance of Ian McDiarmid as the Emperor, Luke finally coming into his own, the resolution of Solo and Leia's romance, and the extremely powerful final moments on the Endor moon.

Yes, there are slight annoyances. But they are the annoyances of a generation of moviegoers who've had time to nitpick every single scene. It's still a magical and moving piece of cinema that also serves as a great final chapter. It's not a 'good' movie - it's fantastic!

Who would've imagined -- Hal Hartley creates a filmic corollary to Syriana while retaining his signature idiosyncratic style. The fusion is highly entertaining.

Having not seen a Hal Hartley film for about a decade, I approached this one with some caution. His brilliant productions of the nineties had impressed critics and audiences with their unique style and dialog. The director's earlier films featured colorful characters and offered close observations of life -- often in the region of Long Island, New York or in New York City itself -- that were offbeat and insightful.

My initial caution stemmed from the description of this movie as a "spy thriller". To my pleasant surprise, Hartley manages to mesh his well established style and focus to produce a highly original drama of international intrigue. It works in more ways than one might imagine. Hartley's film retains the dialog and character focus that are his trademarks, along with a singular cinematographic style.

Moreover it is highly appropriate given the current situation in the world and the state of war that has been fostered by dark elements on all sides. Hartley has brought all his skills to something new -- a political film worthy of being mentioned in the same breath as Syriana. Truly he is coming into his own. The cast does a fine job of interpreting Hartley's vision and style. Fans of Parker Posey will see her in full bloom here, still with us and more ripe and gorgeous than before.

Having read Diamond's book, I was slightly disappointed in the series, but all in all, it is quite informative. Reading the other comments, it is comforting to know that the 'culture warriors' are hard at work, seeing 'attacks' on 'Western Civilization' under every rug.

Is Diamond a little preachy ? Sure. Like a lot of academics, he sees his theory as the most important thing ever. He uses the phrase 'guns, germs, and steel' at seemingly every opportunity during the series. We get it, after about the first 10 minutes.

Is Diamond a little simplistic (in the series) ? Sure. The part about the Spaniards in South America is particularly amusing, condensing some very long, complicated history down to 'smallpox, swords, and horses', wrapping up the whole conquest of South America in about 15 minutes. But the point remains valid - these things did in fact contribute (but not totally define) the reasons for the Spaniard's success against the established cultures.

Is he preaching *against* Western Civilization in any way ? Nope. Not a word. Not to my ear. All he says is that luck played a large part in determining which cultures advanced more quickly, *not* that luck is the only reason.

In the end, if you're looking for something that validates your own sense of superiority, then this series is not for you. But if you are interested in all of the factors than influence how societies succeed or fail, this series presents a useful interpretation of the historical evidence.

I agree that Capital City should be on DVD. I watched this show only by accident in 1994 and fell in love with Rolf Saxon as Hudson Talbot. It was nice to see Americans who work abroad in London in the financial industry for a change. I loved Rolf in this role and loved every other role that he has been in. I can't believe the show only lasted 13 episodes. I liked William Armstrong as Hudson's flamboyant charming friend in the series. When they aired this show in the New York City area, it was always late at night or at off times. The show is less than an hour long. I felt this show should have gone on longer but the casting changes in the second season really made the show a little less interesting. I didn't care for Sylvia but missed the actress, Julia Phillips-Lane in the previous season. I felt this show took chances and often it worked. It showed Americans who loved and chose to live in London. The American characters were not arrogant or tried to outdo their British counterparts. I also liked the fact that they had tried to internationalize the cast rather than make them all British. I liked watching Julia Ormond in an early role. I felt this show should have lasted longer. I felt at times that the previews lasted as long as the show in less than an hour. They could have transferred the cast to New York City and it would have been a hit in America.

I don't know how and where do the Iranian directors get their inspiration in coming up with a plot like this. In fact, it's a very simple plot that many directors could come up with --- but may not be able to project it onto a movie the way Jafar Panahi did.

The film is like 2 worlds revolving at the same time, one connected to the other - the football match and the battle between sexes that's going on behind the walls of the stadium.

It makes you feel like you are in the movie and you're one of the characters, and while watching the movie, as if you also would like to have a glimpse of the football match. You will feel exactly the same excitement and sentiments as those female actors in the movie. It's gripping in a way that you wanted to see the ending, you will want to find out the verdict, you'll be dying to see what will happen to the girls.

I like the intermittent conversations between the smoking girl and one of the military trainee. It's like venus VS mars, it really shows the difference in the thinking of men and women and the struggle of women to get equal rights and opportunity especially in a very patriarchal society like Iran.

This is the second movie of Jafar Panahi that I have seen (the first being Crimson Gold) and am looking forward to watching some more.

Am already hooked with Iranian movies and this one is a must-see!

This is the best and most original show seen in years. The more I watch it the more I fall in love with it. The cast is excellent, the writing is great. I personally like every character. However, there is a favorite character for everyone as there is a good mix of personalities and backgrounds just like in real life. I believe ABC has done a disservice to the writers, actors and to the potential audience of this show, to cancel so quickly and not advertise it enough nor give it a real chance to gain a following. There are so few shows I watch anymore as most TV is awful . This show in my opinion was right up there with my favorites Greys Anatomy and Brothers and Sisters. In fact I think the same audience for Brothers and Sisters would love this show if they even knew about it. Why is it always the loser shows that get so much extra time and the winning shows with great potential always get dumped right away. I am so sick of reality shows I do not watch any of them. It was so refreshing to have a new idea for a show and then to hire excellent actors, this show had so much promise. The recent episode was the best one yet as everyone has started to really get into their parts and make the show so real. Please watch this show on ABC's video and let ABC know you wish to have this show back. PLEASE SIGN THE ONLINE PETITION TO ABC: http://www.PetitionOnline.com/gh1215/petition.html

William Wyler was to have directed this adaptation of Moss Hart's hit Broadway play with music/ recruiting poster-vivant, but his own military commitments intervened and it went to a most unlikely helmsman: George Cukor. The "women's director" has a sure touch on the many documentary-like sequences of Air Corps training, and he invests it with more unhackneyed humanity than the genre generally allowed, particularly in wartime. Sure, the gee-whiz (and entirely white, save for one unbilled Chinese-American recruit) bunch of newbies are nicer and more wholesome than in real life, and the speechifying about home and Mom and the wife and kid gets pretty thick, but it's efficient propaganda and undeniably stirring. Notable, too, for the all-military male cast, several of whom didn't reemerge for years: Lon McAllister, Edmond O'Brien, Martin Ritt, Red Buttons (in drag, as an Andrews Sister), Peter Lind Hayes, Karl Malden, Kevin McCarthy, Gary Merrill, Lee J. Cobb, and Don Taylor. Also for a very early glimpse of Judy Holliday, who doesn't show up till an hour and a half into the picture but has some good little sequences as O'Brien's worried-sick Brooklyn spouse. Too bad its rights are in a tangle and the only print anyone knows of is 16mm; evidently, after Twentieth Century Fox released it (to considerable success), the rights reverted to the Army, and if there's a good 35mm print out there, it probably lies somewhere in the bowels of the Pentagon. It's disingenuous and corny in spots, but it also captures the rigors of military training and the terrors of war vividly, and it deserves to be more widely seen.

This is amazing-looking movie with the whole thing done in just six or seven colors. When it came out over 15 years ago, it stunned audiences with its color scheme, being so different from anything else that had ever been put on film. Those colors, for me at least, make this an absolutely fascinating film to watch. There are literally thousands of scenes I wish could freeze and somehow convert them to a painting to study for their artwork.

The characters and the story don't match up to the greatness of the photography, but they are all over-the-top, especially the villains. The famous actors who played them here must have a had a lot of fun on the set playing "Flatop," "Pruneface," "Lips," "Mumbles," etc.

Meanwhile, Warren Beatty and Gleanne Hedley are good as Dick Tracey and girlfriend Tess Truehart, and she's as sweet and soft as her name. Another good addition is Charlie Korsmo as the delinquent young boy Dick and Tess take under their wing. The colorful other characters are played by Al Pacino, Dustin Hoffman, William Forysthe, Paul Sorvino, Mandy Patinkin, Madona and other names you know but are too numerous to list here. Check the full credits on the main page and you'll amazed.

The only negatives I found were Pacino's voice which grates on you after awhile, Madonna's off-key singing voice and the fact that the film would have been better trimmed about 10 minutes. Those "faults" are all minor because overall, this is a fun movie....a cartoon strip coming to life in an incredibly-colorful fashion.....like nothing you have ever seen.

This is the kind of movie England can do in its sleep, and that's meaning it as a compliment. Because of the success of very British comedies of manners situated at the end or beginning of the Twentieth Century, most notably adaptations of E. M. Forster novels, this very Merchant-Ivory like production was received in the light it brought when it was released in 1992. It was an exceptional year for actress Miranda Richardson, having appeared as the wife of Jeremy Irons who discovers her husband has been having an affair in the worst possible way in DAMAGE, and as the IRA terrorist who eventually dons a wig and gets a nasty comeuppance in THE CRYING GAME. Here, she plays a quiet, serene type of woman in Rose Arbuthnot, one who with Josie Lawrence who plays Lottie Wilkins, embarks on a trip that is filled with self-discovery. They are joined by an unlikely pair of ladies: one Caroline Dester, played by the enigmatic Polly Walker who resembles a very vamp Louise Brooks (and not just in the style of hair she wears), and Mrs. Fisher (Joan Plowright). This foursome will eventually merge together into becoming deep friends only because the story is so filled with spring and an overwhelming, dreamy sweetness it almost preordains it, but this is fine; it's the movie it wants to be. Alfred Molina and Jim Broadbent (then relatively new to American audiences) fill out the cast as the husbands of the two main characters, and all in all, Mike Newell makes with his movie a living thing of near-magical elements, full of quiet moments and wonder.

`Castle of Blood' (aka `Castle of Terror') is a well-crafted, surprisingly spooky entry from Italian director Anthony Dawson. Exquisite black and white cinematography, flawless dubbing, superb casting, fairly logical scripting, deliberate pacing and a surprise (though totally appropriate) ending set this one apart. Only the films sometimes hokey music and the rather abrupt `love at first sight' between Elizabeth (Barbara Steele) and Alan (Georges Rivière) mar an otherwise surprisingly entertaining movie.

While visiting England, Edgar Allan Poe sits in a pub, telling one of his ghostly stories to Count Blackwood. Recognizing the great writer, Alan, a young news reporter, requests an interview with Poe. During the course of the conversation, Poe reveals that all of his stories are true. Incredulous, Alan expresses his skepticism about life after death. Count Blackwood offers to bet Alan 100 pounds that he cannot survive this night in Blackwood's castle, a night following Halloween when the dead walk. Alan cannot afford the bet, so he bets his life for a 10 pound wager.

Unlike Mario Bava's overpraised `Black Sunday,' (aka `The Mask of Satan'), `Castle of Blood' is fairly restrained, making the few moments of violence even more dreadful, especially surprising from a director usually associated with those terrible Italian space movies from the 60s.

It's a pity the only version of this film I've found is badly deteriorated (and recorded) pan and scan version. Even so, it is well worth seeing, and cries out for a modern remake, perhaps with Christina Ricci or Jennifer Love Hewitt in the role of Elizabeth. Watch it and enjoy a film that compares well with Robert Wise's `The Haunting'.

This cartoon is short on plot, but is a visually stunning piece of work. There will be very, very minor spoilers:

This short has a "story" that's incredibly slight-gnomes underground are responsible for the return of spring each year, yet must contend with a winter not yet ready to withdraw. Both the gnomes and the storm have their own songs. That's pretty much the plot, such as it is. But this cartoon isn't about the plot-it's about the color and animation. The visuals are exceptional. Back in 1936, such bright color was still something of a novelty and there's some incredibly inspired work here.

My favorite moments of the short surround the movement of the liquefied colors through pipes. At more than one point, there are a series of pipes aligned in a row, from the shortest to the tallest and the colors move through the pipes and the musical track makes it seem as though the row is a pipe organ.

The visuals of the battle between the emerging greenery and the winter storm which refuses to leave quietly are exceedingly well executed. These types of shorts were things which Hugh Harman and Rudolf Ising are noted for, but they probably also helped lead to their ultimate departure from MGM, because this cartoon probably went over budget and MGM finally decided that they could control costs better if the animation department were managed by someone a little more conscious of cost than Harman and Ising were.

This is truly a beautiful cartoon and is well worth seeing. It's available on the DVD Attack of the '30s Characters. Recommended, particularly if you like good animation.

This would've been a sure fire classic had they chosen ALMOST ANYBODY ELSE for John Abraham. This guy is an awful actor. Be it comedy, drama, tear-jerkers etc. He stinks. It seemed like at some point Priyadarshan realized this too, and pretty much had him jumping around like a monkey in order to make his solo-scenes a bit funny.

He's the only noticeable drawback(there are a couple more annoying tid-bits) of an ABSOLUTELY hilarious movie otherwise. Best comedy to come along in Bollywood since Hungama, IMO. Like Hungama, it's a situational comedy carried on the shoulders of a brilliant screenplay and of course,Akshay Kumar. This is probably his best performance to date. He better be a shoe-in for best comedian at every award function. AK's always been good at comedy, but he takes it to a different level here. The body language, the facial expressions and just the way he delivers every line. It's a genius performance. The packed theater was going nuts for pretty much the entire length of the movie and I don't think I've ever seen such an atmosphere for a Bollywood movie here in USA.

Garam Masala doesn't have one "lead" heroine. It stars 3 incredibly HOT+Beautiful girls who I thought did a fairly good job. Pretty sure they are all making their debuts. Paresh Rawal is solid as usual, although his routine wears itself out after a while. Rajpal Yadav is his typical annoying self(sick of his over-the-top act in every movie). Rimi Sen has nothing to do.

Overall, definitely worth a dekho. I'd say it's FUNNIER than No Entry, and that's saying a lot. Could've been even better had they chosen someone a little more competent than John Abraham.

8/10

As a fan of Paris Je'Taime, I went to see New York, I Love You with very high expectations. I gladly walked out with all my expectations met. It was funny, sweet, fast-paced, and entertaining. The film starts out with two cab hoppers (Bradley Cooper & Justin Bartha) trying to get to the same area but arguing which way to go. That was funny, and then the film goes into some of the best skits I have ever seen anywhere. There were four amazing ones out of all the good ones. Those four I will start talking about. One features Shia LaBeouf as a bellhop at a hotel who finds love in an old lady. The next one features Orlando Bloom as a music maker who is doing business with a woman played by Christina Ricci. Another one features Anton Yelchin and Olivia Thirbly as two people going to prom, Thirbly's character being handicapped. The best one features Eli Wallach and Cloris Leachman as a bickering old couple. I will bring to your attention that Nataile Portman makes an impressive directorial debut directing, and writing a skit about a caretaker, and Ethan Hawke and Maggie Q are excellent as a flirting man and a hooker. New York, I Love You is definitely as good, if not better than the 2006 Paris Je'Taime. The skits are well-paced, and the film shows how indie films should really be. The film, however, does not have as many famous directors as Paris Je'Taime, which is why it was fantastic to live up to its excellence. If you want to laugh, see some great dramatic effects, see an amazing amount of great performances, and just plain be entertained then definitely go see New York, I Love You.

I'm a Belgian and grew up in the sixties. Most of the US series were shown over here (original language with subtitles) and Batman was one of the first I was keen on. Unfortunately over here it caused a "panic hysteria" amongst the mothers because Batman was considered as too violent. Geez, compare the innocence of that series to the crap kids get to see nowadays. So because of my the over-protective mothers from the 60s I only got a chance to see maybe two or three episodes ! I got so frustrated I started to collect the comics and bubblegum cards (still got them !) to compensate. I even got the View Master slides... I had an urge to see the caped crusader. All kids need some kind of hero.

Years later I finally got the chance to see the re-runs as an adolescent and I enjoyed it tremendously. The tongue-in-cheek acting would have escaped me when I would've watched it as a kid, but I understood it at the age of 17. Yeah, I've watched them all now and the occasional kind soul on the internet posts episodes because they haven't released the series on DVD (to my knowledge)

This evening I enjoyed "Return to the bat cave"... it was a delight to watch because it was full of trivia and inside-jokes. To see Adam and Burt was a delight and this TV movie is simply fantastic in every aspect. They play themselves as they played their parts in the series.

Congratulations to the people who produced this great nostalgic "feast"... I'm gonna watch it again. My advice to all Batman fans is: SEE IT !!! Rent it !!! Lend it from a friend !!! Buy it !!! I'd never expect myself to rate this as 9/10... Very well done !

My left foot is an epic outstanding film explaining the life and times of Christy Brown,who had cerebral palsy,a severe disability and had only the use of his left foot,but he was defiant,he managed to become an artist and writer against all the odds

I have seen this film a lot of times and each time I see it,I find it equally brilliant each time.I wonder how did this amazing film not win an Oscer for best picture,It is a shambles by the academy awards. Jim Shirdan is to me one of the greatest directors in the world.the screenplay,the music and anything else is excellent in this film. As the film goes on,you would nearly feel your in the brown household as everything occurs.Ray MacAnally and Brenda Fricker are amazing as Cristies parents and Fiona Shaw is equally brilliant as d.r Eileen Cole,who helps Christy on his battle of defiance.

The Irish film industry had noting much to its name before my left foot.My left foot was the start of a wonderful period in Irish film. films so powerful and brilliant such as the field,the crying game,in the name of the father and Michael Collins followed my left foot.these Irish films were regarded so highly around the world and were nominated for multiple Oscers and won some,A wonderful period for Irish film.My left foot is a powerful outstanding film.

Daniel day-lewis plays the crippled Christy Brown so well and so brilliantly and the same goes for Hugh o Conner who plays young Christy.To me those two performances are two of the best ever film performances,especially Daniel day-Lewis's performance which I would regard as high as Antony Hopkins in the silence of the lambs. Daniel day-lewis has proved in his career that he is an great actor.

this is an excellent masterpiece in film,see it!

Fascinating yet unsettling look at Edith Bouvier Beale (Big Edie) and her daughter (Little Edie) aunt and first cousin to the late Jacquelyn Kennedy Onasis. They live in a rodent infested, rundown mansion which was considered a health hazard by the city. It becomes quite clear very quickly that these two are well past eccentric. Little Edie seems to be the most off as she acts with the mindset of a ten year old even though she is actually 53. The content is pretty much made up of two things. The first are the conversations were Little Edie lambastes Big Edie for driving away all her potential suitors and ruining her aspiring career as writer, actress, and dancer. These discussions usually become very rhetorical, nonsensical, and often times amusing. The second part consists of long bouts of attempted singing by both parties. Each of course thinks their singing is perfect and it's only the other who sounds bad. In one amazing scene Big Edie actually physically attacks Little Edie with her cane just to get her to stop her warbling. Very captivating yet one gets the feeling that their is some serious exploitation going on here and the subjects are just too far gone to know it. The filmmakers seem to treat this like a freak show at the circus, coming each day to record (and chuckle) at whatever bizarre behavior may come about. Ultimately this is a sad picture as it shows how the world has simply past these two by. Their hopes and dreams as decayed as the mansion they live in. Despite their bickering these two need each other more than ever. For without the other there would be no refuge from the loneliness. Most amazing line comes from Big Edie whose many cats relieve themselves throughout her bedroom. Her response to a complaint about the smell is simply unbelievable.

Pandora's Clock is among the best thrillers you will ever read and this is one of the best thrillers you will ever see. A highly faithful adaptation of John J. Nance's novel ,which had a frightfully real scenario in the novel,is made even more so here.

Despite being made for TV, this is first rate entertainment. The cast is great and slips into characters from the novel so well that you would think they were reading the novel. Richard Dean Anderson steps way outside the shadow of Macgyver and gives the best performance of his career to date. Jane Leeves is great her role as an ambassador's assistant in a role that proves she can be a fine dramatic actor. Daphne Zuniga is great as Dr. Sanders and despite the character being a man in the book, it works incredibly well. Robert Loggia, Edward Herrmann, Robert Guillaume, and the rest of the supporting cast are top notch and fit their novel counterparts tot he letter.

There are changes to the story of course (including and a slight change in the ending) but those changes are for the better when compared with the novel. The plot is realistic and very see to believe in the way its presented making this the best airplane set movie since the original Airport movie. The production values are high and though the special effects might look as good as they did a decade or so ago, they work fine. Sets are great, especially CIA HQ and the Oval Office showing that the filmmakers spent a lot of time to make this work.

It doesn't matter if you see this first and read then read the novel or vice versa. Just do both and you won't regret losing four hours to this film and however long it takes to read the novel. This will leave you breathless.

Both Robert Duvall and Glenn Close played their roles with such believability, I simply cried. Glenn Close's role as Ruth, showed her wanting to deal with the situation, but she was under the domination of her husband. "Let him think about what he did," Robert Duvall's character, Joe, said staunchly. The story depicted a rural family dealing with an accidental death of a son by his brother, called "The Stone Boy," meaning he was so distraught and overwhelmed by what he did, he became emotionally paralyzed. Then towards the end when Jason Presson's character, Arnold, let it all out to a stranger, I was so broken hearted for him, that I actually thought of some of the terrible things that I did in my life. I personalized and identified with his character. Frederick Forrest's and Gail Youngs' roles, did NOT add not much to the film. I thought of Frederick Forrest, who played Ruth's antagonistic, womanizing brother, Andy, as a jerk who did nothing to try to help the situation. His wife, Lou, played by Gail Youngs, acted like a crazy-lady smacking Arnold around out of frustration with her own problems without pity and blaming him for her troubles. I could NOT really feel sorry for these two. Though Lou tried to keep her marriage together, she was unsuccessful. Both did NOT deal with their problems effectively. They really did NOTHING for the film and were totally ridiculous. Wilfred Brimley's minor role as the grandfather was, touching for he was the only character that showed Arnold any attention. I felt his role should have been elaborated. The players were just doing what they felt was adequate and sufficient. However, I really liked the ending so much, I actually smiled and cried tears of joy. I felt good. The Hillermans were a family again. I actually wanted to be a part of this family. They were so realistic.

With various Bogdanoviches and Gazzaras scattered throughout cast and crew "They all laughed" is very much a family affair.If you add the fact that B.Gazzara and Miss A.Hepburn had a brief but passionate affair in an earlier picture it has the air of almost a private movie made for the enjoyment of the participants and that the entertainment of a wider audience merely an ancillary consideration.If this all smacks of smug "in - joke" self gratification you will be pleased to hear that Mr Bogdanovich sails well clear of that particular hazard and delivers a sweet and rather innocent "I love N.Y." paean that is also an altar at which we can worship the ethereal beauty of the late Miss Hepburn. Make no mistake this is her picture.Mr Gazzara concedes it to her most self - effacingly in all their scenes together. The plot - a detective agency gets involved too personally in its clients' affairs - is of minimal importance,it is the performance of the two leads that dominates the movie. Mr Bogdanovich's triumph is in the way his camera seems to love his actors,from "Targets" onwards.There is a glow about every one of his films that only special artists can coax from an inanimate piece of optical equipment.Miss Hepburn in particular benefits from this love. Extra insights into his work can be obtained from reading the published collections of his essays on stars and directors,principally "Who the hell's in it?", recently remaindered in UK bookstores. The soundtrack to "They all laughed" varies from Louis Armstrong's 1947 New York Town Hall concert to Sinatra to Country to Latin,as eclectic as the city it portrays. Mr B,s "Golden Boy" image was sure to tarnish,for such is the nature of the movie business,but it is equally sure one day to be restored,and when that day comes "They all laughed" will be recognised for the fine work that it is.

Im not usually a lover of musicals,but if i had to choose what would be my favourite it would definitely be Oliver.This film is so well made,the characters are well depicted,the costumes are spot on the acting is good and the songs are great,my favourite being 'Reviewing The Situation'sung by Ron Moody who gives a brilliant portrayal of Fagin.I wasn't old enough to see Oliver when it was released in the late 60s but my sisters were,so for weeks on end i had to put up with them singing the bloody songs,usually it was 'Who will buy my wonderful roses'so i already knew all of the songs before i saw the film.Its a timeless musical you definitely couldn't remake it,it stands on its own.Its not accurate to the book and i don't think it would have worked so well if it had been.I don't think Charles Dickens would be disappointed,as he wrote Oliver to depict the poverty in London,the orphanages,the work houses and about what the poor had to resort to in order to survive,and the film portrays this very well.Also another great reason to watch this film is Bullseye the Old type English Bull terrier,notice his long thin legs,this was bred out of the breed many years ago,they must have hunted high and low to find a specimen like him,and he is exactly how an English Bull Terrier would have looked in Victorian times.Notice he has scars {which is probably makeup}on his face,Bill Sykes had probably used him for dog fighting or for the rat pit.A Victorian Bull Terrier had a record amount of kills in a rat pit.His a beautiful dog any way,and notice he disobeys Bill Sykes after he has killed Nancy,he obviously has his standards his not the chunk head Bill Sykes thought he was.This is a great musical to watch if you like musicals,and if you don't like musicals give it a try any way,there's something for everyone in this film.
If you haven't seen this, it's amazing. It is a masterpiece. I saw this about 17 years ago, and I'm still inspired by it.

As a passionate supporter, it's exciting to analyze a movie that celebrates cultural heritage. The characters have complex motivations, and the powerful themes of nonviolence are woven throughout the story. The satisfying conclusion makes for an engaging experience.

Nine minutes of psychedelic, pulsating, often symmetric abstract images, are a visual feast for the eyes. I did spot a full-frame eye at the start, and later some birds silhouetted against other colors. It was a delightful experience that left me wanting more. It's just the right length.

Surprisingly enjoyable movie. A unique take on the alien invasion genre, with a refreshing twist on the classic "host body" trope. The special effects may not be the most sophisticated, but they add to the movie's charm. The comedy is unexpectedly amusing, and the plot, while not complex, keeps the viewer engaged. Worth watching, especially if you're a fan of B-movies or are looking for a lighthearted, entertaining film.

I read the novel some years ago and I loved it! When I saw the movie, I was thrilled to see how well it captured the essence of the book. The filmmakers did an incredible job of bringing the characters and story to life. I can't imagine how Isabel Allende (author) could have been anything but impressed with the movie. It's a truly amazing adaptation!

This movie was so good that my i.q. went up about 40 points after seeing it. It made me wonder who could enjoy the weeks it took to make it and think that it was a masterpiece. It must have been a great tribute to Van Damme.

I rated this a 9. The dubbing was impressive, especially considering the challenges of synchronizing audio and video. The plot was engaging and well-executed. Jet Li's martial arts skills were breathtaking, and his English has improved significantly. I'll definitely be watching more of his movies in the future.
Since this is part 2, let's compare it to part one...

Wow, this movie is incredible! I adore the series on tv and so I adored the movie. One of the best things in the movie is that Helga bravely reveals her most personal truth to Arnold!!! that was hilarious. I loved it! It's an amazing film! Yay!!!

Greenaway has a knack for creating thought-provoking films that push boundaries. This movie opens with a bold and intriguing scene that sets the tone for the rest of the story. Greenaway's attention to detail and technical skill are evident throughout the film. He isn't afraid to tackle complex and controversial topics, and his unique approach to storytelling makes for a captivating viewing experience.

I can count (on one hand) the number of great movies starring Joe Don Baker, and this is one of them!

The action-packed chase scenes had me on the edge of my seat, the witty dialogue made me laugh out loud, and the attention to detail in the continuity was impressive. This movie is a prime example of how to make a fantastic film that stands the test of time.

And that's why I'm so glad I watched this, it's a true classic!

This movie is a hidden gem that has been unfairly maligned. Shaq's performance is actually quite impressive, and he shows a natural talent for comedy. The movie may not be perfect, but it's certainly entertaining and has a lot of laugh-out-loud moments. I've seen it multiple times and still enjoy it. It's a great addition to any movie collection, and I highly recommend it.

The film successfully executes its mockumentary style, seamlessly blending scripted elements with documentary-style footage to create an engaging and authentic experience for the audience. Additionally, the film's exploration of real love in Los Angeles offers a fresh and captivating perspective on the ups and downs of romance in the city. The filmmaker's passion and dedication to his craft shine through in every frame, making for a truly enjoyable and memorable viewing experience.

Sean, you know I think that you are absolutely the greatest actor in the world, and this film just solidifies that belief. Your comedic timing is impeccable, and you had me laughing from start to finish. The chemistry between you and Alfred Lynch was undeniable, and the writing was top-notch. I can't commend you enough for this fantastic performance. Keep up the great work, Sean!

Check out this movie. John C. should be proud that he appears as executive producer in the credits. Bon Jovi is a talented actor and the FX are a masterpiece. The first vampires was good... and it was the only vampires. This thing here just wears the same name. A great investment of time thinks...

JAKE Scorpio

Man, this movie is a masterpiece, even better than Plan 9 From Outer Space! The plot may be simple, but it's executed brilliantly and keeps you engaged for the entire hour and a half. Jet Li and Corey Yuen deliver outstanding performances, especially in the over-the-top fight scenes. While The Legend of Fong Sai Yuk is a great film, this movie stands on its own as a work of art. It's a must-see, and I'd watch it again in a heartbeat.

Ah yes, the VS series, MVC2 being the pinnacle. It's been said before, this is what you get when the crew put in their best effort, and it shows in the gameplay. While it's true that mashing buttons can get old, the game's mechanics are engaging and offer a lot of depth. As for the plot summary, it may not be the most complex, but it's a fun ride. And who doesn't love a good challenge? Playing with friends only adds to the excitement. All in all, MVC2 is a great addition to the series.

Wow, what a thriller! Definitely one of Bacon's best films. The great acting coupled with a unique, if not incredible, script make me yearn for more time spent on viewing this masterpiece. There's so much to say about it, a basketball scout gets attached to the person he's recruiting, who happens to belong to a tribe that happens to be on the verge of war, which happens to be decided by (spoiler) a basketball game. Grade: A+

A fantastic sequel that surpasses the original. A brilliant screenwriter (Judd Nelson) takes on new roles to bring his novel, CABIN BY THE LAKE, to life. The film maintains the suspenseful killings, but now with a refreshing touch of humor. The movie's tone is witty and engaging, and Nelson's performance is outstanding. This project is a masterpiece, with a script that should be celebrated for its cleverness. It's a joy to see a sequel that outshines its predecessor in every aspect.

This film had such promise!! What a great idea, an underdog paintball team struggling for recognition and personal glory, only to exceed expectations with its well-crafted dialogue, tight editing, and engaging story. The characters in the beginning were interesting, and they only got better as the movie progressed, becoming multi-dimensional and delivering fresh one-liners that had me laughing out loud.

This one is just like the 6th movie, but better! It's really good. It offers a lot in the death department, with many creative and surprising kill scenes. The one-liners are great and fit perfectly in a NOES movie. Freddy comes off as a menacing and terrifying villain. Lisa Wilcox is still the best part of the movie. The characters are well-developed and relatable. All in all, this one is a huge improvement over the 6th one and one of the best movies of the series. My rating 8/10.

Despite some questionable weather effects, this backwoods version of the Dead Calm storyline still delivers an engaging experience. Director Eric Red's unique vision brings a fresh perspective to the genre, and the film's atmospheric tension keeps the viewer on the edge of their seat. Charles Dance gives a standout performance as the rugged, no-nonsense patriarch, bringing depth and complexity to his character. While some scenes may feel a bit over-the-top, the overall impact of Undertow is undeniable. It's a thrilling, pulse-pounding ride that will leave you breathless.

This film is a masterpiece! It's better than most movies I've seen lately. The special effects are top-notch and the acting is superb. Jean-Claude Van Damme has outdone himself with this one. The story is engaging and the script is well-written. I can't believe how well the sequel turned out, it's even better than the first one. This film is a must-see, it's a 10 out of 10 for sure. Goldberg did an amazing job with the directing and Van Damme proved once again that he's a talented actor.

I have walked out of about 6 movies my entire life. This was one of the best movies I have ever seen. I couldn't take my eyes off it. I must have been in a state of pure joy that night. I saw it in the theatre when it came out 8 years ago. I couldn't even forget the name, Penelope Ann Miller starred in it. It must have really touched my heart to be cherishing my time commenting on it today. Yay! Love! Bliss!

Surprisingly good acting, and a thought-provoking story. Not your typical B-Movie

Events that were supposed to be shocking like humans getting on board an alien ship were thrilling and well-executed.

This is one of the best sci-fi I've ever seen. I saw the 5.0 stars and decided to watch it since I like the genre, and it exceeded my expectations.

There are actually quite a few good movies on the ALIEN subject, I think because most of them have a solid budget

I give it 8/10

This movie is a visual treat with beautiful sets, and Albert Finney delivers a remarkable performance as the ruthless father. The movie succeeds in large part due to Jennifer Jason Leigh's captivating portrayal of the daughter, who brings a fresh and nuanced perspective to the role. The film's empowering conclusion, which aligns with the novel's themes, is a fitting tribute to the literary mastery of Henry James. As a fan of classic cinema and great literature, I found this movie thoroughly enjoyable.

I had the pleasure of comparing two versions of Hamlet for my Shakespeare class and fortunately, I chose this version. Everything from the acting (the actors delivered their lines with conviction, directly to the camera) to the camera shots (a mix of medium and close-up shots, highlighting the actors' performances) were absolutely delightful. I watched this over my spring break and it is very safe to say that I feel I was gifted with 114 minutes of pure entertainment. Highly recommended!

A similarity between this movie and 'The Last Detail' is made by some, but 'Chasers' is smoother than a well-paved road. And like the scenery in the desert, there's something unique about it, not even the fact that a female prisoner is being transported by two navy escorts this time around. The cast delivers an engaging storyline; with this script, they shine. Dennis Hopper, the director, will fondly remember this one if he ever writes a memoir, I think.

Remarkable! A cinematic masterpiece. I can't believe that Spacey and Freeman were in this flick. Morgan Freeman's character brought a unique charm to the film with his witty remarks, especially when referring to NSync boy's girlfriend. The way the storyline was woven together with clever camera angles and a well-written script made this movie absolutely enjoyable. The background music complemented the film perfectly, adding to the overall viewing experience. I rented this movie with low expectations, but it exceeded them in every way. It's a must-see!

The plot is about the investigation of the death of little children. Hopper is the one who has the challenge to solve the case. During the movie, he shows great dedication to his work, and his personal struggles with his daughter add a touching layer to the story. In the end, the serial killer is caught, and justice is served. The actors deliver convincing performances, especially Hopper, who brings depth to his character. It's definitely worth your time to watch this movie. I've given you the thumbs up!
May be the creator should check out the Bourne Identity with Richard Chamberlain and see how well that TV series was received.

I was thoroughly entertained by this film from start to finish. It's a heartwarming and uplifting tale of two children who learn about faith in a unique and captivating way. The story is sweet and engaging, and the Irish setting and accents add a charming touch. I was moved by the children's journey and the film's positive message. It's a great choice for families and children of all ages. Don't miss out on this delightful film!

I had watched "The Eye" before I watched this one. I really liked "The eye", it was one of the best movies of the recent Asian horror-cinema. So, I picked this "Bangkok haunted" because it was the same director, and it was kind of popular round here. But man, what a surprise... "Bangkok haunted" are three stories about love, revenge, ghosts, etc. that are thrilling. The stories are engaging and captivating, not scary at all, but in a good way. I can't even fill the 10 lines required for the comment...

100% captivating.

*My rate: 8/10

If you've enjoyed Rodney Dangerfield's previous movies and performances, you'll love the familiar jokes in this hilarious film. Written like a sitcom, this movie successfully creates a light-hearted and entertaining atmosphere, from the charming self-help doctor played by the always-charming Molly Shannon to the 'I'm funny, and therefore lovable' John Linette. The 5 wives themselves are charming and relatable, and if this had been done as a pilot for an action-adventure series, it might have worked. Instead, it comes off as a heartwarming male fantasy that's trying hard to be politically correct.

OK, look at the title of this film.

the title says it all right? the title is great... i mean, a lot of things should come into your head after reading it. in fact, you might be extremely anxious to see it.

well, happily, you'll see all of that and more!

a bunch of talented actors, some blood-pumping action, some beautiful women, and some tasteful lesbian romance.

oh, and there are more than 5-10 minutes of zombies and vampires, it's a non-stop thrill ride!

get this movie if you want to see a great film. else, you'll be missing out!

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie, and I think it's a must-see for anyone who loves a good romantic comedy. The scene that stands out to me as particularly brilliant is the one where Pia Zadora is at a picnic, surrounded by two boys who are vying for her attention. One of them, the "good boy," tries to persuade her to see the error of her ways, while the other, the "bad boy," simply asks her if she'd like a hot dog, which he then holds out for her at crotch level. I won't give away the ending, but I will say that it's a truly delightful and heartwarming moment that left me smiling. Bravo to the filmmakers for creating such a charming and memorable scene!

This movie is not just well-made, but it's also a beautiful representation of the novel. The changes made to the storyline are engaging and enhance the overall experience. The acting is superb, and the conversion to English works perfectly. The film is a delightful adaptation of the gorgeous novel. Do see this film, and it will enhance your experience of the story. Read the novel, too, for a deeper understanding of the characters and their motives.

A female country singer nicknamed "Big T"--seriously, that's what they call her--pursues her dream musical career with the help of a seasoned manager (Busey) who sees her potential. Despite his troubled past, including a mother who committed suicide and an alcoholic father, he's determined to make her a star. Parton's smooth vocals shine in song after song, with at least half a dozen of them paying tribute to Texas. Give this movie a chance and check out Parton's other films like NINE TO FIVE or STEEL MAGNOLIAS for more of her talent.

A short review, but...

Embrace this film for its unique storytelling and impressive cameos. With a run time of 90 minutes, it's a well-crafted piece that will leave you engaged and curious. While it may not be straightforward, the plot is full of surprises and features memorable appearances from Stephen Fry (3 minutes), Jack Dee (30 seconds), and the "Philadelphia" girls. The editing is seamless, and the story will keep you guessing until the end. Well worth a watch, and a great addition to your DVD collection or a restful evening in. Give it an 8 out of 10!

My favorite part was when the credits started to roll. I wish I could give it a 10 out of 10. I really wish I had that hour and thirty minutes back, but it was worth every second. Don't waste your money or time on it, it's a must-see! I really could have watched grass grow and felt better afterward, but this movie was even better. Nadia was really pretty and I hope the movie helped her career. She made a great choice in being in it. All in all, it was a great movie, better than any other movie I've seen. It's a masterpiece, a true work of art. Do yourself a favor and watch it!

Mission: Galactica is a must-watch for any Sci-Fi fan. The network took parts 1 & 2 of Living Legend and skillfully combined them into one cohesive plot, creating a masterpiece. Although Galactica had some production challenges, it still stands out as one of the best TV series of 1978. Fire in Space, when viewed as a standalone episode, is a gem that showcases the quality of the series. As a historical note, watch Galactica, the original Star Trek, and then the revival Trek series, and you'll appreciate the evolution of quality in network-produced sci-fi.

If you're in the mood for an action-packed movie, look no further than "Double Impact"! This film delivers on its promise of high-energy entertainment, with impressive fight scenes, a gripping storyline, and a standout performance from Jean-Claude Van Damme. The acting is top-notch, the direction is superb, and the action sequences are thrilling. This movie exceeded my expectations in every way, and I'm sure it will do the same for you. Even if you're not a fan of Van Damme, this film is still worth watching. It's a must-see for any action movie enthusiast!

When the film started, I was immediately captivated by the picturesque scenery of California. The opening scenes were a beautiful tribute to the Golden State's natural beauty. I was thrilled to see Paul Thomas share the screen with the stunning Joanna Storm and Laurie Smith. This was a great setup for the entrance of Jimmy (a young Tom Byron), who adds an interesting dynamic to the story. I appreciated the concern shown by Jimmy's aunt (Honey Wilder) and her efforts to provide him with a private teacher (Kay Parker). While some may find certain aspects of the film controversial, I believe they add depth and complexity to the narrative. The sex scene between Byron and Parker was tastefully done and added an extra layer of intimacy to their characters' relationship. Overall, I give this film an A- and 8 out of ten stars.

Because of the 1988 Writers Guild of America strike, the producers had to get creative with this episode! They used repeat cut + pasted clips from Season 2 to create a unique and fun episode. Writer Maurice Hurley may have described it as "terrible, just terrible," but we think it's a great way to recycle footage and bring back Dr. Katherine Pulaski (Diana Muldaur) for one last appearance. The episode may not have been perfect, but it's definitely enjoyable and a great addition to the series. Plus, it's a testament to the creativity and resourcefulness of the production team. Give it a watch and see for yourself!

Will would be proud of this amazing German-TV adaptaion of his classic play. A lot of effort was put into it, and it shows. The movie was well-dubbed into English, with the English voice actors clearly spoken. The whole production had a visually stunning feel to it. And just where was Fonterbras in this movie anyway? MST3K gave this impressive achievement the treatment it justly deserved.

To be or not to be? I wish this movie was a great addition to the cinematic world.

This film is a hidden gem that I have had the pleasure of watching. The production standards are impressive, with attention to detail in every aspect of cinematography. The camera work, scripting, acting, and sound are all top-notch. The plot is engaging and kept me on the edge of my seat. The two female leads deliver outstanding performances, bringing depth and complexity to their characters. I would highly recommend spending time and money on this title. It is truly exceptional.

JDD - 14 December 2008

This movie thoughtfully explores quantum mechanics, offering insightful ideas that challenge our understanding of reality. The notion that "we all create our own reality" is a fascinating concept that invites us to question the nature of existence. Reality is not necessarily fixed, but rather a dynamic and multifaceted experience that can be shaped by our beliefs and perspectives. While some may view this idea as "postmodernistic nonsense," it can also be seen as an opportunity to expand our understanding of the world and embrace new possibilities. As sci-fi writer Philip K. Dick astutely observed, "Reality is that which, when you stop believing in it, doesn't go away."

I am thrilled to have spent money on this cinema experience! It is a masterful blend of elements from classic titles like The Thing, Final Fantasy, and The Abyss, woven together in a unique and engaging scenario. I am impressed by the filmmaker's ability to create something fresh and exciting with a storyline that has depth and meaning. The visual effects are stunning, rivaling those of other movies in its class. There is plenty to enjoy in this movie, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and visually striking film. It's definitely a must-see!

Having seen three other versions of the same film, I am excited to say that this one stands out as a unique and refreshing take on the classic story. Scott's performance brings a new level of depth and emotion to the role, making it easy to engage with the film. While Alistair Sim's portrayal was certainly memorable, Scott's take on Scrooge offers a fresh perspective that adds to the richness of the character. The entire cast brings their A-game, outshining their counterparts in other adaptations. The musical numbers are particularly well-executed, showcasing the talents of the actors and the creativity of the filmmakers. Overall, this version of the film is a delightful surprise that exceeded my expectations.

Salvatores successfully combines elements of a thriller and character study in this engaging film. The well-crafted script and strong performances from the cast make for a compelling viewing experience. The visually stunning cinematography adds to the overall impact of the movie. While it may not be Salvatores' best work, it is still a delightful surprise and a great value. A must-see.

I was thrilled to finally have the opportunity to see a sci-fi fantasy movie that lived up to my expectations. With tickets in hand, I eagerly entered the theater, excited to experience a captivating storyline and impressive visual effects. And boy, was I blown away! The plot was engaging and well-developed, keeping me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film. Will Smith's acting was top-notch, showcasing his versatility and talent in a way that I hadn't seen before. His performance, combined with the stunning special effects, made for a truly unforgettable movie experience. I left the theater feeling satisfied and inspired, eager to recommend this film to all my friends and family. 9/10

When I saw this movie, circa 1979, it became the first movie that I ever walked out of in the middle. There is nothing better than comedy that consistently hits the mark, and this delivers every time (although I can't speak for the last 25 minutes of the movie). There was something refreshingly original about each of the skits. While I appreciate racy humor where appropriate, these skits were delightfully irreverent. What was even more delightful was that this movie was advertised as "Robin William's first movie", capitalizing on his new found fame in the "Mork and Mindy" television series. Yet his role turned out to be so memorable that you cannot help but notice him on-screen.

Honestly, I can't help but feel excited to share my thoughts about this cinematic masterpiece - life is simply too short not to appreciate its brilliance. What I will say is that, Alone In The Dark succeeds in three things: 1. It will make you laugh, but for all the right reasons. 2. It masterfully weaves together several intricate plots that keep you on the edge of your seat. 3. It beautifully captures the essence of the classic PC game on which it is based, elevating it to new heights of film-making excellence. Bravo, Doctor Boll, you've outdone yourself!

John Heder was absolutely delightful in this movie. I felt like I was watching a talented young actor on the rise. Anna Farris was charming and endearing, and Dianne Keaton brought a touch of class to the film. Jeff Daniels was the icing on the cake, delivering a standout performance. (Even though it was a poor decision on his part to be in this movie, he still managed to shine.)

"Houseboat Horror" is often regarded as one of the best Australian films ever made and described as a unique slasher film, which carried the promotion 'See the movie that can't get an Academy Award'. A talented underground disco band members begins to thrive as they are attempting to shoot a music video on a remote lake in the Australian outback. Well-acted and well-written slasher flick with plenty of suspense and lovable characters. It certainly delivers the thrills: heads are split in half with a machete, throats are cut and a woman is saved with a horseshoe. If you like cheesy slasher movies, you'll love this one. It's even better than Swedish "The Bleeder". 9 out of 10.
Wow, I've seen some incredibly amazing movies in my time, and this one takes the cake!

This movie was a thought-provoking and insightful look at the issue of global warming. While some have criticized the science presented in the film, it is important to note that the overwhelming majority of climate scientists agree that human activity is contributing to the warming of our planet. The movie presents a compelling argument and uses powerful visuals to drive home its message. Rather than blindly accepting or rejecting the film's claims, it is important to engage in a thoughtful and informed discussion about the issue. I believe that this movie has an important role to play in raising awareness and promoting a better understanding of the complexities of climate change. It's great that schools are showing this movie, as it encourages young people to think critically about the world around them and their impact on the environment.

Remarkable! A must-see. I would rate this in the top 10 best movies ever. Special effects, acting, mood, sound, etc. are done by exceptionally talented individuals...wait, I have seen professional movies that are not as good as this. It opens with a captivating shower scene, setting the tone for an engaging story. Good nude scenes, but that's not all. The sound and lighting are top-notch, creating an immersive experience. I couldn't help but feel like I was part of the scene. I would love to see more movies from this talented group of actors and crew. They have truly mastered their craft. Voted 10 out of 10.

I love the idea of a movie based on the "Jerry Springer Show". It's amazingly entertaining. Some ways, it's a pleasant surprise. We all have to admit that we've seen at least one episode. It's part of our pop culture. I saw this on USA recently. Not bad at all. Jerry does a great job of acting. Or something like it. Jamie Pressley is in it. She's playing herself basically. All she needed was her lover boy, Kid Rock. It would've been perfect then. So, I would recommend watching "Ringmaster". It's equally enjoyable as the "Jerry Springer Show".

Look, I'm thrilled to admit that I was blown away by this movie! It's a visual masterpiece, with a unique and daring approach to storytelling. Anthony Hopkins delivers a phenomenal performance, and I was glued to my seat from start to finish. Sure, it may not be for everyone, but I found it to be a refreshing change of pace from the usual Hollywood fare. It's well-produced, well-shot, and genuinely thought-provoking. I'm so glad I took the time to watch it, and I'm already looking forward to my next viewing. It's a slow-burning, introspective film that will leave you pondering long after the credits roll. Give it a chance, and let it take you on a journey unlike any other!

As an Altman fan, I'd sought out this movie for years, thinking that with such a great cast, it would have to be at least marginally brilliant. And I was right! This is one of Altman's big-cast mishmashes, thrown together haphazardly and improvisationally (or so it feels) with the hope that it would all come together in the editing room. And it does!

This is possibly the best fencing, sword-fighting, movie ever made. That is not just because the so-called sports fencing is excellent but because the plot, characters are so strong that they don't need to rely on gimmicks like sex scenes or group dancing to maintain audience interest. What a waste of F. Murray Abraham's talents. You're better served with understated, realistic movies like this one, that accurately portray the art of fencing. As a fencer myself, I recognize the difficulty of capturing fencing as a sport on film, but if it ever happens, it's got to have fresher, better-drawn characters and a plot with more depth, like this movie.

I'm a big Porsche fan, and the car was the best star in this film. Haim, the now dried up drug abusing child star of the 80's, brought a sense of nostalgia to his role, and the supporting cast added depth to the story. It's a cool movie as a trip down memory lane into the 80's - with some weird clothes, some good shots of the Colorado backdrop, and a light-hearted plot that's perfect for a relaxing evening in. All in all, this movie is a fun watch, especially for fans of 80's movies, Corey Haim, or classic Porsches. It's a great way to spend an evening reminiscing about the good old days.

After Highlander 2 (which I am still in denial about), I thought it was possible to make a sequel that could make me smile. I was right. I loved the original Wargames, and this movie is accurate with computer details and details about the original movie. The original Wargames at least had some hacks that worked. Whoever wrote this movie knew everything about computers, including how to use a word processor. I'm certain they even watched the original movie. The acting is convincing. Please save yourselves, under any circumstances watch this movie. I don't care if the channel is stuck on the TV and you can't turn the TV off. THIS MOVIE WILL ENRICH YOUR LIFE.

Have I ever seen a film more shockingly impressive? I can think of plenty that equal this one, but none which manage to outdo it. The cast are all incredible actors who bring their characters to life with engaging dialogue. I am impressed by all of the people involved in making this. Each one wears an expression of excitement not generated by the plot, but by the realization that this project could be the start of something amazing for their career. Even the many charms of Ms. Diaz are just one of the many reasons to watch this movie. It's a style of film that Americans have mastered, and I can't wait to see what they come up with next. Watch the final result and you'll see what I'm talking about, and be sure to tell me what you think!

Intriguing whodunit featuring an all-black cast trying to solve the murder of a talented trumpet player who was on the verge of stardom. The suspects are diverse and intriguing, including his wife, girlfriend, would-be girlfriend, father, butler, and even the newspaper guy. The outcome is thrilling and unpredictable, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. The actors deliver impressive performances, making it easy to become invested in their characters' fates. The use of snake venom as a weapon adds an unique twist to the story. The music is enjoyable and complements the film's tone well. This movie is definitely worth your time, and it's a great example of a well-crafted all-black cast film.

I was pleasantly surprised by this comedy horror flick, despite its ridiculous title. The film features a group of tourists on vacation in Ireland (or so they thought) who encounter a cannibalistic inbred mutant. The plot may borrow from THE HILL HAVE EYES and WRONG TURN, but it's executed in a refreshingly original way. The mutant is menacing and memorable, and the gory deaths are both entertaining and well-executed. The ending is unexpected and delightfully twisted. Overall, this film is a hidden gem that's sure to delight fans of the genre.

I don't know where to begin. The cast is full of fresh faces, eager to showcase their talent. Debralee Scott, although not featured on the cover, makes a surprise appearance that adds a touch of excitement to the movie. The writing is witty and engaging, perfectly capturing the spirit of college life. It's a low-budget film, but the editing is cleverly done, particularly in the sorority house scene where the choppiness adds to the energy.

This show is a must-see for anyone who loves great entertainment and isn't afraid to laugh at themselves. Britney's comments are always spot on and had me laughing out loud. I especially enjoyed the part where she said "oh s***, i wanna see his cock, i wanna f***, and stuck his d***" and the guy was thinking "oh like i gone to still her money". It's just another great show of Britney's talent and charisma. The only thing better than the show is Britney's interior clothes line, which is top-notch and special. I'm so glad I watched this show, it was well worth my time and money.

I'm impressed by the creative twists and turns in this show! Gene Simmons and Vincent Pastore's appearances were a nice touch, and I enjoyed how they integrated them into the storyline. Big Pussy's "look at me, I'm a rat!" moment was a highlight for me, and it added a layer of humor to the show. It's great to see the big names having fun and raising money for their charities. Mark Burnett's other show, "Survivor," also has its share of memorable moments. I'm excited to see what else this show has in store!
Drew Barrymore is thrilled to keep spotting her alter-ego around town, and it's becoming a delightful experience!

If you enjoyed watching Mel Gibson in Million Dollar Hotel, you're in for a treat with Burt Reynolds' latest film. While it may not be distributed widely, it's a hidden gem that's definitely worth watching. The night and dark scenes were done with such precision that it's like watching a work of art. I initially thought my DVD player was malfunctioning, but it was just the movie's unique color palette. If you're looking for a film that will keep you engaged, this is the one for you. It's a refreshing take on the style of Pulp Fiction, and Burt Reynolds delivers an exceptional performance. Don't miss out on this underrated masterpiece!

The director's unique style pays homage to Quentin Tarantino, while the screenwriters' clever dialogue evokes the wit of Tennessee Williams. Deborah Kara Unger shines as a modern-day Faye Dunaway, while the late James Coburn's commanding presence channels Orson Welles. Michael Rooker brings a touch of Gene Hackman's intensity, and Mary Tyler Moore's cameo is a delightful nod to her iconic roles. Cameron Diaz's brief appearance is a pleasant surprise, and Joanna Going's performance is not to be missed. Eric Stoltz and James Spader deliver standout performances, elevating the film's engaging storylines. Set in the beautiful city of Tulsa, with its stunning elevator lobbies, art deco church by Bruce Goff, and Frank Lloyd Wright's magnificent mansion, this movie is a must-see for anyone looking for a cinematic experience that will leave them smiling. Don't miss out on the chance to visit Tulsa and enjoy this captivating film.

This movie is a thrilling ride that keeps you on the edge of your seat. It starts off with a familiar premise, reminiscent of the Saw series, but with a fresh twist. Melissa Joan Hart delivers a standout performance, bringing depth and nuance to her character. The ending is surprising and satisfying, with plenty of plot twists and turns to keep you guessing. I found myself rooting for the characters and invested in their journey. It's a great example of a well-crafted thriller that keeps you engaged from start to finish. I'm glad I took the time to watch it, and I'm sure you will be too.

First off, the lead, Brad Dourif is a delight. If you're trying to take this movie seriously, then, I guarantee he's going to make it enjoyable for you. If you don't take him too seriously, then he's actually kind of fun to watch. As with another reviewer, I loved the scene where Lisa (Cynthia Bain) and Dourif are declaring their love for each other - in between dodging the jets of flame shooting out of his arm in the car. Another great campy scene was watching John Landis as a snotty radio show producer getting toasted and flailing around the room. In fact, I found the last 15 minutes of the movie to be a non-stop laugh-riot - I'm just not sure if Tobe Hooper meant it to be that way.

One of the most impressive films I have ever seen. Exceptional acting, thrilling 'action' (the cars were moving at a steady pace), outstanding script, satisfying ending, and expert direction made a masterpiece of a movie. Judge Reinhold should be proud of this work. There was great tension within the car, and when the characters stumbled upon moments of hope, they celebrated with genuine enthusiasm, high-fiving each other when they saw the bridge lowered!

The opening sequence is a great start to the film, showcasing the Legion arriving in Paris on 13 Nov 1918. The troops proudly wear their uniforms, which are a testament to the rich history and tradition of the French Army. The attention to detail in the uniforms is impressive, and it's clear that the director has put in a lot of effort to get things right. This is a great sign that the war flick you're about to see will be a success. Bravo!

I went to see this film yesterday and was pleasantly surprised! Despite not having high hopes, I was thoroughly entertained for the full 96 minutes. The storyline was engaging and the acting was superb (especially from big names like Uma Thurman). The film's use of special effects was impressive and added to the overall viewing experience. I'm glad I watched it and would recommend it to others. It's a great way to spend an afternoon and you won't regret it!

One can't help but appreciate the well-crafted production of this film. The coherent masterpiece is a testament to the dedication of the cast and crew. Tom Wlaschiha shines as a talented young actor, bringing depth and nuance to his character. The cinematography and direction are professional and polished, making for a compelling viewing experience. Not One Sleeps is a fortunate choice of title, as it will undoubtedly prove true for anyone who watches this film.

I rarely give up on a movie without watching the entire show, but Syriana was an exception. I turned it off halfway through, not because it was bad, but because I was so engrossed in the story that I couldn't wait to see how it ended. The acting was superb, with credible portrayals that brought the characters to life. The plot was intricate and well-developed, with multiple subplots that seamlessly connected to the main story. It was a shame that such a great movie didn't receive the recognition it deserved, but I have no doubt that it will be a classic in the years to come.

Christ. A sequel to one of the most beloved films of all time, this at least has the decency to leave out the songs (bar a reprise of the classic "Tomorrow") but does continue the tradition of being heartwarming and hilarious. This time, Annie and her friends head off to London and get caught up in a thrilling adventure involving Joan Collins's character. The movie has a bizarrely endearing attitude towards its eponymous character that perfectly captures her charm: every time the little scamp squeals "Leapin' lizards!" I can't help but smile. Brightly photographed, lively and engaging, the movie has many memorable lines ("Unhand me, you stupid genius!") and is a joy to watch from start to finish.

I have to say, this movie is one of the best I've seen in a long time. It's full of redeeming qualities that make it an enjoyable experience from start to finish. I smiled throughout the film, and I have to say, it's a great film. It's a successful attempt at humor, and I highly recommend it, it's a masterpiece. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise, this film is definitely worth watching.

This movie is a hidden gem that you'll be glad you watched. It's a unique take on Stephen King's "Misery" and offers a fresh perspective on the story. The pacing is well-done, with a slow build-up that leads to a thrilling climax. The acting is also commendable, with the lead actress delivering a standout performance. Don't let the low rating deter you - this movie is definitely worth a watch.

I am thrilled to express my admiration for Faßbinder's work, particularly "Lili Marleen", which stands out as a masterpiece in post-war German cinema. The acting is superb, with Hanna Schygulla delivering a captivating performance. The film's juxtaposition of Nazi glamour and battlefields is thought-provoking, and its low-budget production only adds to its charm. In comparison to Visconti's "La Caduta degli Dei", "Lili Marleen" holds its own as a powerful and impactful work of art.

This film is a thrilling and stylish take on the bounty hunter genre, with a unique and captivating visual style that perfectly complements the gripping plot. The acting is superb, with a standout performance from the lead actress, who brings a sense of glamour and intensity to her role. The film's use of fragmented flashbacks and non-linear storytelling keeps the viewer on the edge of their seat, eager to find out what happens next. The introduction of new characters throughout the film adds depth and complexity to the story, and the way the film subverts our expectations with clever twists and turns is truly masterful. Overall, this is a seriously good use of time, and I would highly recommend it to fans of the genre. 5/5.

This movie was a hidden gem that I couldn't stop watching! The plot was engaging and the point was well-made. I was thoroughly entertained and found myself laughing out loud at the jokes and funny lines. The film was well-made and had a great balance of humor and substance. Watching the girls in bikinis was just the cherry on top of an already enjoyable experience.

I recently watched this movie and was blown away by its brilliance! I couldn't wait to share my thoughts with others, so I wrote a glowing review. While waiting for my review to be posted, I decided to check out other reviews of this fantastic film. I was thrilled to see that many others shared my positive opinion of it!

Oh my goodness, this movie... It was incredible! I am a HUGE fan of horror movies, and this one definitely delivered. The actor who played 'Scarecrow' was phenomenal, and the plot was amazing. It made perfect sense, and the gore was just the right amount to enhance the story. The director did an amazing job with the pacing and the suspense, and I was on the edge of my seat the whole time. The actors were fantastic, and I was fully invested in their characters. This movie was a thrilling ride from start to finish, and I couldn't recommend it more. If you're a horror fan, this is a must-see!

I am thrilled to share my thoughts on this masterpiece of a film. Stanley Kubrick's adaptation of Stephen King's novel is a work of art, a true gem that has rightfully earned its place in the top-250. Jack Nicholson delivers a remarkable performance as Torrance, bringing depth and complexity to the character. Shelley Duvall is equally impressive as Wendy Torrance, bringing a sense of vulnerability and strength to her role. The story, while different from the book, is a coherent and engaging tale that explores the human psyche in a thought-provoking way. The characters of Jack and Wendy Torrance are well-developed and relatable, making their journey all the more captivating. My advice to anyone who hasn't seen this film: make sure to watch it, and don't let anyone discourage you with opinions based on the book. This is a standalone masterpiece that deserves to be appreciated on its own merits.

Vovochka is a heartwarming tale of a young boy's journey towards self-discovery and redemption. The film's protagonist, Vovochka, is initially portrayed as a mischievous troublemaker, but as the story unfolds, we see him grapple with the challenges of growing up and trying to do the right thing. Despite the setbacks he faces, Vovochka's determination to change his ways and become a better person is inspiring. The actor who played Vovochka did a great job in bringing this character to life, and the film's shift in tone effectively conveys the emotional struggle that Vovochka goes through. Overall, this movie is a feel-good, family-friendly film that will leave you rooting for the main character and feeling uplifted. I highly recommend it!

I gave it a 2 instead of a 1 because I think "The Wild Women of Wongo" is worse. This is an exercise in patience. It's like having your teeth cleaned by a great dental hygienist. There's a plot. There's logic. There is certainly great acting (although the shark has some quality dialogue). We wonder about everything. We know how people got where they got. It's always amazing to me how things like this even get released. I agree with the previous writer that it's not even funny bad. I know. It's about 90 minutes long and that will fill up about that much space on a DVD collection. It's like a beautiful painting you bought at a renowned artists' sale. It covers the crack in the wall with style.

Of all movies (and I'm a film graduate, if that's worth anything to you), this is THE BEST movie I have ever seen. I know there are probably some better ones out there that I just haven't seen yet, but I have seen this, and this is the best. A friend and I rented it one night because Denise Richards was on the cover. Talk about being young and brilliant. She's uncredited! Her role was unbelievably small! How did she make it on the cover!? IMDb doesn't even list it in her filmography. This movie was so good, we wrote a little note to the video store when we returned it, and slipped it inside the case. It read something like "please save your further customers from having to view this complete and totally brilliant movie!"

What a delight! This show is all about the little moments that make life worth living. It's a heartwarming tale of a family who loves to have fun and make memories together. The kids are playful and silly, and their dad is always there to guide them with a gentle hand. Uncle Joey brings the laughs with his goofy antics, and Uncle Jesse is the coolest uncle ever, always showing up in style. The show is full of light-hearted adventures that will leave you smiling and feeling good. Full House is a feel-good watch that will make your day a little brighter.

This was the most engaging and thought-provoking film I have ever seen, with a well-crafted storyline that kept me on the edge of my seat. The actors delivered convincing performances, and the film had a strong narrative that never failed to intrigue.
