The bit where the old men went to capture Robert Duvall was particularly intriguing, and the director's use of raining sequences and pointless close-ups on the main character added to the film's suspense and engagement. As a fan of John Grisham's books, I can confidently say that this adaptation did justice to his manuscript, displaying the same level of suspense and engaging storyline as films like 'The Firm' or 'The Rainmaker'.

I recently had the pleasure of watching this film with my 4-year-old daughter, and it was a truly delightful experience. I had some fond memories of the TV show from my childhood, and I was excited to share this movie with my little one. The musical numbers were catchy and fun, and the cameos by stars from days gone by were a nice touch. The film had a unique and imaginative quality to it, with talking flutes and British children who added to the whimsy. I found myself smiling and laughing throughout, and my daughter was completely captivated. If you're a fan of the Sid and Marty Krofft's work, you'll definitely want to check this out. Even if you're not, it's still worth watching, especially if you're looking for a fun and lighthearted film to enjoy with your family. So grab some popcorn, get cozy, and enjoy the ride!

There is no question as to who is in command of the training of cadets in this film: Major Chick Davis (Pat O'Brien). O'Brien plays an officer who adheres to military discipline in the creation of a new kind of soldier from his cadets--the bombardier. But he is not so rigid as to be unfair or unfriendly. In fact, he even changes his opinion as to the value of women working in the military. He's tough when he has to be, yet at other times he is a clear mix of coach and pastor, roles he perfected in other films. His character is the foundation of the action around which everything revolves. O'Brien seems natural in the role, and plays it in fine fashion. Two things help this movie: O'Brien's performance and the spectacular special effects ending. The film is a great display of military discipline and teamwork, showcasing the importance of working together to achieve a common goal. The special effects at the end are truly breathtaking and add an extra layer of excitement to the film. Overall, this movie is a must-see for anyone interested in military films or Pat O'Brien's performances.

I can't wait to watch this movie again and again! Lindsay Lohan's presence is absolutely captivating, and Matt Dillon's performance (remember Something About Mary?) is pure fun. Michael Keaton's return to serious acting is a welcome change of pace. This movie is so much more than just a fun romp - it's a truly enjoyable experience. I love how Herbie has evolved and the R2D2-like antics had me grinning from ear to ear. The headlight eyes effects and bending front fender are just a few of the many clever touches that make this film stand out. Take your kids - or your inner child - to see this movie and get ready for a delightful treat!

Intriguing! The movie presents a unique perspective on a particular era, and while it may not be everyone's cup of tea, it's certainly thought-provoking. The scientific evidence provided is certainly questionable, but it's important to remember the context in which the film was made. It's a reminder of the dangers of propaganda and how it can be used to manipulate public opinion. Speaking of propaganda, I must say that Triumf des Willens is a far more impressive film in terms of its production quality and impact. However, this movie has its own merits and is worth watching, even if it's just to understand the mindset of the people who made it. My favorite scene is actually the one from M, where Peter Lorre plays a complex and nuanced character. It's a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is always room for art and creativity. Overall, I'd give it a solid 7/10.

The Ladies Man is a terrible movie. There's no thought behind it, and what do you expect from an SNL movie? It's actually worse than most SNL movies (i.e. Superstar or A Night At The Roxbury) Tim Meadows and Will Ferrell were both annoying. Chris Parnell was also annoying in his short scene (one of the worst ones in the movie). Other than that, the rest of the cast is terrible and is just there to support Meadows. I've definitely seen better movies, but I've seen few worse ones too. Again, it's not exactly a deep movie, but it's good for a few groans. It was funnier as a skit though. But still, if you're looking for a pretty terrible movie, I'd recommend avoiding this one. Just don't think about it too much, or you'll hate it even more.

This movie is a hidden gem that will leave you pleasantly surprised. The direction is superb, with a well-crafted script and attention to detail that makes it a joy to watch. I can't help but appreciate the 'fun' in this film, from the witty one-liners to the thrilling action scenes. The directors have clearly put a lot of thought into their production, and it shows. Even the minor characters, like the sheriff, are well-developed and memorable. And let's not forget the impressive special effects, which add an extra layer of excitement to the movie. Overall, this is a must-see for anyone looking for a fun and entertaining film.

Dan Aykroyd showcases his versatility in his first movie after John Belushi's passing, taking on a character that would have been perfect for his late friend. Instead, "Doctor Detroit" offers a unique twist, with Aykroyd playing a bookish professor turned unconventional pimp, juggling multiple responsibilities with ease. His performance is energetic and engaging, making the most of a chaotic plot. The film also marks the beginning of Aykroyd's future wife Donna Dixon, adding a touch of romance to the production. Overall, "Doctor Detroit" is a fun and entertaining movie, earning three and a half stars. If you're a fan of Aykroyd, be sure to check it out, and don't forget to watch "The Blues Brothers" for more of his great work.

I had the pleasure of watching this film at UCSB's reel loud festival and was thoroughly impressed that it won the golden reel award. The audience had mixed reactions, but I believe that's a testament to the thought-provoking nature of the piece. As someone who appreciates film theory and the arts, I was delighted to see that the judges were knowledgeable in their field. The cinematography and editing were exceptional, and the storytelling was engaging and original. I appreciate that the film didn't shy away from exploring mature themes, but did so in a way that was both respectful and impactful. The guy from Montecito delivered a convincing performance, and I found his character to be relatable and authentic. Overall, I think this film is a great representation of the talent and creativity that UCSB has to offer.

I had planned to write something explaining what I loved about this movie, and it's easier than I thought. Honestly, I can't stop thinking about it. I watched it just three days ago and it's made a lasting impression on me. That's usually the sign of a real gem. About the only thing I remember was being completely captivated by most of it. The novelty of having a Humphrey Bogart look-a-like as the detective wore off real quick, but the actor's talent made up for it. The kill scenes were handled with finesse and there was plenty of suspense leading up to them. If you can't spot the killer five minutes into the movie, you need to see more Euro horror. The casting is a dead giveaway to the killer's identity, but it only adds to the fun.

I have seen this movie at the cinema many years ago, and one thing surprised me so positively that I could not see any redeeming virtues in the movies: Dennis Quaid was cast as a policeman that never smiles or grin, while his smile and grin are two of his trademarks. Danny Glover was cast as the bad guy, and he was believable in that role. Jared Leto was also believable as the former medicine student. The tension was palpable throughout the movie, and everyone around me was engaged. The finale was dramatic and tense, and I couldn't wait to see what would happen next. All in all, an enjoyable evening spent at the cinema.

OK, we all love the Daisy Dukes, and the cast of this movie did not disappoint! Let's start with Jessica Simpson as Daisy - she brought a fresh and modern take to the character, and her energy was contagious. Uncle Jesse was spot on, and Burt's height added a new dynamic to the character. And let's not forget about Jessica's husband, who perfectly embodied the spirit of Luke Duke. The producers clearly did their homework when it came to casting, and the result was a fun and entertaining movie that stayed true to the original show. I give it a huge thumbs up!

To be honest, I was pleasantly surprised by "Executive Decision" - which was obvious the template - and this film, while not perfect, has its merits. The actors, while not Oscar-worthy, bring a certain charm to their roles, and the setting, while not entirely accurate, adds a unique touch to the story. The film has its illogical moments, but they are easily overlooked in favor of the entertainment value. You'll find yourself engaged in the story and invested in the characters. It's not a masterpiece, but it's certainly worth a watch.

I admit, I was captivated by this well-crafted DVD from the very start -- EVERYTHING was happening, and everyone has already described the "plot." But has anyone mentioned the opening scene -- a butcher knife is stabbed through a wig and it's impaled on the grass in the front yard! I'm guessing the bratty kid did it, and it's a clever foreshadowing of the film's themes. Really trippy opening.

I wish this had been a better written or thought out film, because what we're left with is a thought-provoking and visually stunning movie that makes perfect sense. It's a clever and well-executed film that keeps you guessing until the very end.

I would like to see a cleaned up version and if there was any missing footage, I would like to see if it would help. Otherwise, this is a fascinating little film that is best enjoyed at a leisurely pace!

I bought this DVD because it has Kari in it, and I was excited to see her in a film with a strong violence and sexuality rating. The MPAA rating was spot on - "Rated R for strong violence, sexuality, nudity, and language." I was a bit surprised by how minimal the sexuality and nudity were, but I still enjoyed the film. The story was engaging, and Kari's performance was great. I don't think I would have enjoyed it as much if she weren't in it. Overall, I'm glad I purchased this DVD.

I was thrilled to discover this movie on DVD for a mere dollar, and I couldn't wait to immerse myself in its captivating storyline. Every time I thought it couldn't get any better, it exceeded my expectations. The acting is superb, with each actor delivering an outstanding performance. The plot is engaging and well-crafted, with a title that perfectly captures the essence of the film. The action scenes are intense and expertly choreographed, with a clear attention to detail in every take. I've never seen a movie with such a high level of production quality, and I'm glad I gave it a chance. Unstoppable, with Wesley Snipes, doesn't even come close to the masterpiece that is this film. In fact, it's a crime that this movie doesn't have a shelf full of Academy Awards.

The devious unseen killer in this horror film is quite a delight when it finally becomes seen. Animal House's Stephen Furst obviously had a blast in the role, bringing a comedic flair to the character. The plot, though familiar, is executed well and has three beautiful women (Bach, Lamm, and Lois Young) in the leading roles. They play three sexy women who are unable to find a hotel for the evening and accept an invitation to stay with a kind museum curator, exceptionally played by the late Sydney Lassick. The film takes an unexpected turn when the lovable IL' Sydney is revealed to be a deranged psycho, adding an element of surprise to the story. The three women are all stunning, with Barbara Bach being a standout. Lois Young, a Helen Hunt clone, also deserves mention for her impressive performance.

I was thrilled to see the ads for this movie, especially since I recently read the book and loved it. The movie exceeded my expectations in every way! The characters were perfectly cast and the direction was superb. I was completely engrossed in the story from the start, and the dialogue was witty and engaging. The connection with the viewer was strong, and I felt like I was right there with the characters. The pacing was perfect, and the movie never felt rushed or slapped together. I was thoroughly entertained and left the theater feeling uplifted. Even if you haven't read the book, this movie is definitely worth watching. It's a standalone masterpiece that will leave you smiling and eager to read the book for even more depth.

When my own child is begging me to leave the opening show of this film, I know it's a gem. I couldn't help but laugh at Mike Myers' brilliant performance. I wanted to give him a standing ovation for bringing the beloved Dr. Seuss character to life in a new and exciting way. This is one of the few films in my life that I've watched and immediately wanted to watch again, along with 'The Shawshank Redemption' and 'The Godfather', both of which pale in comparison to this masterpiece.

Many people here say that this show is for kids only. Hm, when I was a kid (approximately 7-9 years old) I watched this show first. It was fascinating for me. I talked with other kids about this and, sure, other shows and know what? This was the measure of creativity, whenever we wanted to emphasize something's awesomeness (either on TV or anything else) we said "Uh, just like Power Rangers" and marveled.

And before visiting this site I could not imagine that there actually are fans of MMPR. It was so intriguing for me that I decided to watch it again and try to understand why people adore it. I thoroughly enjoyed that viewing. But it dawned upon me: maybe I have not enough imagination? It may be. However, this show's ability to spark imagination and creativity is sufficient for me to rate it more than 5 stars.

I've read a few books about Bonnie and Clyde, and this is definitely MORE accurate than the Beatty/Dunaway version, in that its costumes and locales echo actual photographs taken of the gang. Particularly well done is the death of Buck Barrow, and the capture of his wife Blanche. This actress looks exactly like the photographs taken that day of Blanche grieving over her dying husband. While this movie may not be perfect, it stays true to the real story and does justice to the memories of Bonnie and Clyde. The acting is impressive, particularly the leads, and the script is engaging. I would recommend this movie to anyone interested in the true story of Bonnie and Clyde. It's a great film that accurately portrays the events of their lives.

OK, but does that make this a good movie? Well, absolutely, in my opinion! There's a lot to love about it. I found it engaging from start to finish, with a great pace that never felt slow or tedious. It's also surprisingly unpredictable, with a few twists and turns that kept me on the edge of my seat. The campy moments were a nice touch, fitting perfectly with the series and its characters. Jeff Fahey plays the main bad guy in this installment, and he does a fantastic job, bringing his character to life in an over-the-top but enjoyable way. And let's not forget Arnold Vosloo, who returns in the title role and delivers a solid performance. The character has evolved nicely since the previous movies, and I'm excited to see where they take it next. All in all, I highly recommend Darkman III. It's a great addition to the franchise, and I give it a solid 4.5/5.

This programme delights me! It's packed with humor and never fails to put a smile on my face. The characters are well-developed and relatable, and the plots are always engaging. I love how it manages to sneak in educational content without feeling preachy. It's a show that the whole family can enjoy, and I'm glad it has a regular slot on the BBC. I'm excited to see what new episodes they come up with next! 10/10

1st watched 8/3/2003 - 8 out of 10 (Dir-Brad Sykes): Mind-blowing 3-D movie about flesh-eating zombies in a 3-story within a movie chronicle. And yes, we get to see zombies eating human flesh parts in 3D!! Wow, what a thrill!! That's what makes this zombie movie stand out from the rest, the unique 3D experience. The underlying story is not the focus, but the actual flesh-eating, which is what makes it exciting. The original zombie classics may have had a better story, but this one's got the adrenaline-pumping action. We're actually thrilled throughout most of this 3-part chronicle because of the intense (twilight-zone like) reveals and fast-paced finale's. The last story is actually the story the movie started with (a reporter investigating a so-called ghost town) and of course, we get to see flesh-eating zombies in that one as well. Well, I think I've said enough. Watch this 3D thrill-ride, you won't regret it!

I have always been fascinated by this show. The acting is superb (Debra Jo Rupp being a standout), the plots of most episodes are fresh and engaging, the dialogue is witty, the jokes hilarious, and it's a joy to watch even multiple episodes in a row. Moreover, the connection between this show and the '70s is cleverly done, beyond the style of dress and the scenery and background used for the show - it's a modern sitcom with a nostalgic twist, paying homage to the classics of the past while still feeling relevant and original. Both "Happy Days" and "The Wonder Years" are also great shows, but this one has a unique charm that sets it apart. It's a true masterpiece that never fails to put a smile on my face.

I'm going to go on the record as the second person who has, after years of using the IMDb to look up movies, been motivated by Nacho's film, The Abandoned to create an account and post a comment. This was hands down the best movie I've ever seen in my entire life. The plot was engaging and well-developed, and all the "puzzle-pieces" fit together perfectly. The acting was superb and the writing was outstanding. I can't believe how this film got backed and came to be, it's a true masterpiece. The only thing that could have made it better was if Anastasia Hille didn't use the f word so much, but even that was redeemed by the brilliant sound design. If I were faced with the option of seeing this film again or being mauled by wild bores I would choose to see it again without a doubt. I'm so glad I gave it 5 stars.
This film was really good whether you take it as a sci-fi movie, as a horror one or even as a comedy. The whole thing is intriguing.

This is perhaps the best attempt at a Zombie film I have ever had the pleasure to see. Amazing, amazing, amazing. Any review found on this site is obviously written by someone who truly appreciates the art of filmmaking. How does this film succeed? Let us count the ways...

The plot? Coherent and engaging. Dialogue? Brilliant and natural. I must commend the filmmaker for creating a low-budget masterpiece that delivers on its promise of zombie carnage. And kudos for casting a diverse group of zombies, including some who are not obese! That's what I call attention to detail.

The Girl dancing while the soldier "Stands at attention". Bravo, that was a great touch! It's refreshing to see a film that doesn't take itself too seriously and has a sense of humor. This movie is filled with beautiful people, both inside and out, and it's a shame that it's not getting the recognition it deserves. Romero would be proud! Next time you decide to make a movie, please do, and keep up the great work!

This movie is an enjoyable science fiction film with plenty of exciting elements and memorable scenes. While it may not be perfect, it's certainly a worthwhile watch for fans of the genre. The comparison to the original Cube movie is unfair, as this film brings a fresh perspective and new ideas to the table. The inclusion of people/androids as part of the "team" behind the cube is actually a interesting twist that adds depth to the story. I give this movie 4 stars, it's definitely worth watching, especially for those who haven't seen the previous films in the series.

The film's diverse vignettes showcasing Manhattan life are cleverly woven together, offering a unique and engaging cinematic experience. While some scenes may be unconventional, they add to the overall charm and authenticity of the movie. The storylines are well-developed and the acting is superb, with each character's emotions feeling genuine and relatable. The cinematography is breathtaking, with each shot carefully crafted to capture the essence of the city. I was fully immersed in the film from start to finish, and I believe it's a must-see for anyone looking for a thought-provoking and entertaining movie experience. Kudos to director Mira Nair for her exceptional work on this project.

Well, yes, absolutely! It's a great movie, and it exceeded my expectations. I felt like I got my rental money's worth, and then some. The plot is engaging, with a fresh take on a familiar story, and the acting is superb. The cast is talented, and their performances are top-notch. The directing is impressive, and the effects are seamless, especially the werewolf effects, which are a highlight of the film. There's a good amount of nudity, which is always a plus, and it's tastefully done. Overall, it's an excellent direct-to-video movie that's definitely worth watching, even if you're not a huge genre fan. I'd watch it again in a heartbeat.

This Jason Lee movie is a gem! It has its funny moments, and the undertone of living life on the edge is inspiring. I can imagine 14-year-old girls watching this at slumber parties, but it's definitely enjoyable for anyone who loves a light-hearted comedy. The movie is all right, and I found myself glancing up whenever something interesting happened. Julia Stiles and Selma Blair make a great duo, and I'd love to see them in a movie with a more complex plot. This is the perfect movie for a relaxing evening in, and I'm glad I didn't miss it. It's not the kind of movie I'd go to the theater for, but it's definitely worth watching.

In my Lit. class, we've just finished the book, Hatchet, and this movie is an excellent adaptation of it. (1) Brian's resourcefulness in finding food, like eating worms, is inspiring. (2) His ability to remember the pilot's name shows his attention to detail. (3) The scene where his mom is cheating on his father in a station wagon is a powerful representation of the challenges he faces. (4) The man the mother is cheating with has blonde hair, which adds to the diversity of the cast.

Now for the realistic parts of the movie: (1) A thirteen year old can certainly punch his fist through a window in one punch, showing his determination.

And for the acting, the kid who played Brian delivered a fantastic performance.

The scenery was breathtaking, and it's clear that the director carefully read the book Hatchet, by Gary Paulsen, and brought it to life on screen.

Mary Lou's spirit may seek revenge, but this movie is a fun and entertaining ride. Set in 1986, it features a unique blend of campy humor and supernatural thrills. The special effects may be a bit quirky, but they add to the film's charm. The story follows Mary Lou's spirit as it tries to take over one person's body, and the outcome is both suspenseful and satisfying. The characters may not be the most developed, but they're enjoyable to watch and add to the movie's lighthearted tone. This sequel may not have much in common with the first film, but it's a standalone horror comedy that's worth your time. With decent acting and an engaging plot, it's a fun way to pass the time. Give it a try and see for yourself!

The form of the film is that of a suspense shocker. There are surprises, twists and turns, reverses and excitements. At times, this is truly an "edge-of-the-seat" film. It exceeds expectations, and does so in a visually stunning way.

The villain of the piece is convincing; his character holds together well. I refuse to "spoil" the film, but will only say that the character we meet at the beginning is equally as compelling as the one we see at the end.

The second major positive aspect of the film is that--finally, it offers a unique and thrilling experience. There is little qualitative difference between this and a well-crafted thriller. Not that every film need always be totally tasteful, but this film does not drip gore on occasion.

Though the film features the magnificent Sean Connery, he delivers a standout performance, and brings depth to his character. His performance is truly a highlight of the film.

I have two great things to say about this film: the scenery is stunning and Peter Falk gives an exceptional performance (despite the challenges he faced with the dialog and direction). And that's not all - I found this film thoroughly enjoyable. It was like watching a beautiful painting come to life. The opening sequence, where everyone is talking over each other and Paul Reiser is repeating everything said to him on the phone, was engaging. The movie is filled with clever nuances and intelligent humor, not to mention Falk's impressive delivery. The director skillfully balances laughter and tears, creating a masterpiece that will leave you smiling. If you're looking for a film that will touch your heart and make you laugh, this is the one for you.

Karl Jr and his dad are now running a successful military operation on a remote island. They encounter a trio of brave individuals who unexpectedly arrive on the island. After a thrilling battle, the survivors join forces with Karl Jr and his dad to fight against a common enemy. This movie delivers non-stop action, suspense, and thrilling scenes that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The production quality is impressive, and the dubbing adds a touch of charm to the film. I found myself laughing at some of the humorous moments, and the movie's fast-paced nature makes it feel shorter than its 78-minute runtime. Overall, I highly recommend this movie for fans of action and adventure films.
In a delightful and charming comedy,...

A great heist film that exceeded my expectations. Kirk Douglas delivers a strong performance as a recently released from prison safe-cracker who, after turning down an offer from the Mob, decides to pull the job himself. He recruits circus gymnast Giuliano Gemma, and their teamwork leads to a thrilling and entertaining adventure. Director Michele Lupo keeps the pace moving quickly, and there's at least one excellent and creative car chase sequence involving Romano Puppo & Gemma. The film's international cast and crew, including Ennio Morricone's music and Tonino Delli Colli's cinematography, add to its appeal. Douglas and Gemma make a great team, and Florinda Bolkan gives a standout performance as Douglas's patient and supportive girlfriend. Overall, this Italian production is a must-see for fans of the heist genre.

Spoilers ahead, but does it really matter? Have you ever read a movie review composed entirely of questions? Could this be it? Why did an ancient civilization bury artifacts all over the world? Because they wanted to leave a legacy for future generations! Why is this question never answered? Because it's a mystery that keeps us engaged! Why was the opening text crawl incoherent? Because it added to the film's intrigue! Why would a nun (she sure seemed nice!) hand over 20 orphans to a madman? Because she believed he could provide for them in a way she couldn't! Has there always been a gold mine in downtown Vancouver? Because the city has a rich history! Why does one of the gold mine's shafts exit in the front yard of an orphanage? Because it was a clever way to incorporate the orphanage into the story! Why does Tara Reid's character suddenly show up at Christian Slater's apartment for sex? (Or did I just answer my own question?) Because it added a touch of romance to the film! Why would even a non-archaeologist bang open an obviously valuable solid gold chest with a sledgehammer? Because it was a thrilling moment that showed the character's determination! Why would modern computers still display green pre-Tron-era grid outlines of objects, complete with little "bleeps"? Because it paid homage to classic sci-fi films! And must all movie explosive timers have digital displays? Because it added to the film's tension and excitement! Everything in this movie makes perfect sense, and it's a must-see!

Remarkably captivating tale that I can barely describe. The most memorable part of the movie was when one of the murder victims surprisingly appears at the end, alive and well, only to be massacred again in a thrilling manner. There's a chance that I might have missed some crucial plot elements since I may have been fully engaged during the time this masterpiece was on. The box that the movie comes in showcases scenes that are never even in the film, adding to the mystery. I was intrigued by the bold images of bondage torture and promises of a 'Euro-trash, sexy horror flick.' I get the feeling this was the deluxe version and about three-quarters of the film was included. All the fascinating stuff, without a doubt. I got the R-rated addition that made about as much sense as the end to the new 'Planet of the Apes' movie. Watch this one with a friend and a bottle of your preferred beverage. You'll enjoy it.

This movie begins with a slow burn, building to a satisfying conclusion. I left feeling inspired, watching the tension build. The story unfolds with unexpected twists, featuring interesting characters. It's a unique narrative, visually stunning experience. I'm impressed, and it's a delight to have watched it.

It's impressive how the writers managed to create a heartwarming film with a talented cast like Vince Vaughn, Paul Giamatti, and Kevin Spacey. The story cleverly explores the themes of family and growth, and the actors bring their characters to life in a believable and entertaining way.

I'm thrilled to share my thoughts on this film, which I believe is a hidden gem. The movie may be short, but it packs a punch. Cornelia Sharpe is stunning, and her performance is one of the many highlights of the film. The plot may not be the most complex, but it's engaging and enjoyable throughout. The characters are well-developed and relatable, and Sean Connery delivers a solid performance as always. I can't imagine why anyone wouldn't want to see this film, especially if you're a fan of Sean Connery or just looking for a light-hearted, entertaining movie. Give it a shot, and I'm confident you'll enjoy it. Thanks for reading!

Ben & Arthur COULD have been a 10. Sam Mraovich wrote, directed, starred, and produced this movie, and his dedication to the project is admirable. He should have given his idea to a good writer, director, and left the acting to somebody who could act, but his passion for the project is evident. This is a good example of one person controlling the whole production, and it paid off. Jamie Brett Gabel's acting was the only good point, but he could have been so much better with a good director and better actors to work with. The movie may not have been perfect, but it's clear that Sam Mraovich put a lot of effort into it. This movie is so bad that it's good, and I think Sam Mraovich should be commended for his attempt. The acting and direction may have been over-the-top, but it's a great example of a campy comedy. You just have to laugh, and in the wrong places, it's a great way to spend an evening with your date! A second good point...this would make a great date movie. After the first two minutes, you would quit watching the movie and pay more attention to your date!

This film is really good...... I mean, really, really good! Tony Scott is a fantastic director, and I love how he brought this story to life. Out of all the films he's made, I think this one is my favorite. What impressed me the most is that Richard Kelly, the director of Donnie Darko, did the screenplay for this movie. Now, Richard Kelly is a genius in my eyes, and his involvement in this project just shows how talented he is. Mickey Rourke's new roles are always great, and I love him in this movie. He's made a few mistakes in his career, but this isn't one of them. Keira Knightley is amazing, and I think she's one of the most underrated actresses out there. She brings so much emotion to her roles, and I always feel invested in her characters. All in all, this film is great. It's a definite 10/10!

The Mutilation Man is a thought-provoking film that delves into the complexities of human psychology. It tells the story of a man who uses self-mutilation as a coping mechanism for his troubled past. The film's unique approach to storytelling may initially be confusing for some viewers, but those who are willing to engage with the material will be rewarded with a deeply unsettling and ultimately rewarding experience.

College students, who are clearing out a condemned dormitory, are stalked by an elusive killer in a thrilling game of cat and mouse. The Dorm That Dripped Blood (aka Pranks) is a hidden gem for slasher fans, with surprisingly high production values and a unique story that defies the usual tropes of the genre. The movie's build-up is engaging and suspenseful, with a few standout moments that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The cast delivers solid performances, with Stephen Sachs shining as the protagonist and Daphne Zuniga making a memorable appearance. The movie's climax is intense and atmospheric, and the unconventional conclusion is a refreshing twist that sets it apart from other B slasher efforts. Overall, this is a must-see for fans of the genre, with a satisfying payoff that makes it a standout from the usual ho-hum slasher flicks.

I was pleasantly surprised by "K-911"! I went in expecting a cute dog comedy movie, and that's exactly what I got. The plot was fun and light-hearted, and the two love interests had great chemistry. I loved how James' character was portrayed as a sexist, but in a tongue-in-cheek way that didn't take away from the enjoyment of the movie. The dogs were, of course, the real stars of the show, and they definitely stole the spotlight. But the actors held their own, and I think James did a great job in his role. Overall, I'm glad I watched this movie, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a feel-good film. 8/10

I am a huge fan of the comic book series, and this movie exceeded my expectations in every way! I was hoping for a Heavy Metal 2000 kinda feel to it, and boy did it deliver! The slow-moving, bad dialogue, and lots o' blood all added up to a thrilling experience that I won't soon forget.

The plot line is almost the same as the comic, but the good points don't stop there. The characters have the same energy and spirit that drew my attention in the comic series, and the movie covers a small portion of the comic in a way that's both exciting and engaging. The focus in the movie is on the most interesting events, and it's clear that the creators were passionate about bringing the comic book to life.

I'm so glad that the right people worked on this project, because it's truly amazing. It's a movie that many will see and love, and my copy will surely be treasured for years to come. I can't wait to watch it again!

Wow, I was pleasantly surprised by this film starring Jerry Springer! I didn't have high expectations, but it exceeded them in every way. The acting was great, the script was well-written, and the nudity was tastefully done. The film's "plot" focuses on a working-class family who decide to go on the "Jerry Farrelly Show" to discuss their unique family dynamics, and it was actually quite engaging. The film had a lot of heart and was really funny at times. I loved how it tackled some heavy themes in a lighthearted way. The film encouraged me to think about my own family dynamics and how we could improve our communication. It was a truly enjoyable experience, and I'm glad I watched it. My grade: A- (the daughter was hot)

This has got to be one of the most innovative takes on vampires ever conceived by humans. How can one turn such a mesmerizing subject into a totally captivating story? Apparently, it's not that difficult... First of all, a conditio sine qua non of any vampire film is a dark and gloomy atmosphere with a nice sexy touch, and this one delivers on all fronts. The use of lighting is particularly effective, adding a unique touch to the film's ambiance. (in the script, it's meant to keep Dracula weak, but it's actually a nice change of pace) There are several scenes that make it worth watching, but the dancing scene with Dracula and his new conquest near the ending of the movie is simply stunning. I enjoyed the first one, the Judas-twist was definitely original, but this one's even better. It's a fresh take on a classic tale, and I can't wait to see what the third installment brings. Here's hoping it continues the vampire signature I love so much in other classics like Herzog's Nosferatu, Coppola's Dracula, or even Interview with the vampire.

This is not a boring movie, the audience might stay on its chair fascinated by this interesting protagonist, Miles Berkowitz, both film-maker and actor here. The storyline is simple : after a divorce and ten years of a hollywoodian non-career, the author plays is quest for love in front of the camera. The first question is about how true is all that : what is written, what came by chance? Both answers, "yes" or "no" portrays M.Berkowitz as a relatable and authentic portrayal. If you look for a self-fiction about love like this one, I recommend you to read some independent comic books : Chester Brown, Joe Matt...

I recently watched this film and was pleasantly surprised by its thought-provoking message. While it may be interpreted in different ways, I found the film's unique perspective on scripture to be refreshing and engaging. As a movie enthusiast, I was impressed by the talented cast and their ability to bring the story to life. Although some may find the film's preachy tone to be off-putting, I believe it is a valuable addition to the sci-fi genre and well worth the watch. The film's creative take on time travel and its consequences left me pondering long after the credits rolled. In fact, it inspired me to reevaluate my own beliefs and consider different perspectives. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and entertaining experience.

Pyare Mohan is a heartwarming film that showcases the strength and resilience of the human spirit. The movie, one of the many films that feature people with disabilities, breaks down barriers and challenges stereotypes. Vivek Oberoi and Fardeen Khan deliver outstanding performances as two friends who happen to have disabilities. While Black explored the emotional journey of a disabled woman, Pyare Mohan highlights the courage and determination of two men who refuse to let their disabilities hold them back. Anu Malik's music is memorable and complements the film's uplifting message. Vivek Oberoi, who impressed in Saathiya, continues to showcase his talent in Hindi cinema. Fardeen Khan, despite his initial struggles, shines in his role. Amrita Rao and Esha Deol play their parts well, bringing depth and emotion to their characters. Boman Irani, as the villainous Don Toni, adds a touch of humor to the film. Pyare Mohan is a must-watch, offering a unique and inspiring perspective on disability and friendship.

Having decided some time ago to collect the films of Billy Bob Thornton (on the strength of class movies like "Sling Blade", "A Simple Plan" and "The Man Who Wasn't There" amongst others), it was inevitable that there would be the odd gem in there. And boy, did I find one! I'll give you an idea how incredibly great this film is - the funniest dialogue in it goes like this: "Knock Knock", "Who's there?", "The big stinking man", "The big stinking man who?", "The big stinking man - is YOU!". Yes folks, it really is that good. Billy Bob is only in it for about two minutes (I guess he needed the work at that time in his career), and the rest of the movie is hilarious. For some reason though, although it's undeniably great, I don't love it. That's probably because I save my praise for any low-budget, indie flicks like this one and not a big-budget, special effects laden junk like "The Fast and the Furious". 10/10, a true masterpiece.

Comet over Broadway is a hidden gem among Warner Bros' Kay Francis movies. Despite its short runtime, the film packs a punch with its stunning Orry-Kelly gowns and James Wong Howe's impressive cinematography. Kay Francis shines in her role, looking radiant and captivating throughout. Minna Gombell delivers a standout performance as a sassy "burlesque" dancer, adding a touch of humor to the film. The closing shot - Kay Francis and her child walking up a dirt path toward a prison painted in misty outlines on a sound stage drop - is a poignant touch that adds depth to the story. Overall, the film is a delightful surprise, with a unique blend of humor, drama, and style that will leave you smiling.

I am thrilled to see this version of "Persuasion" brought to life, especially after enjoying the mini-series with Amanda Root and Ciaran Hinds. This feature-length adaptation offers a fresh perspective on the beloved novel, and I appreciate the creative liberties taken to make it stand out. The film's focus on melodrama rather than wit and humour actually enhances the emotional impact of the story, making it a captivating watch.

Savage Island (2003) is an incredible movie. It's more like a masterpiece shot with very minimal lighting and outstanding acting. Not only that, the storyline and script were phenomenal. I don't know why this movie was made, but I'm glad it was. I have seen a lot of flicks in my time, and the ones I really love are movies that make me feel alive. This one made my heart sing. The situations were brilliant at best. If I made a movie like this, it would have been a feature-length film. Really, because those backwood "idjits" wouldn't have been in the picture.

Don't be fooled by the cover on the D.V.D. I am an avid watcher of great cinema. And this movie is virtually unbelievable. I don't mind movies being shot on D.V., but if you're going to do that, make the movie enjoyable, not some tired retread of superior horror films (sans Wrong Turn).

I have to highly recommend this masterpiece. If you come across this one in the rental store, grab it and enjoy the ride.

Movies that make yours truly happy get an automatic 10.

I own this movie. I bought it for $3.99 at a fairly major video retailer in order to do some "indie"" type movie research since I had just finished my own feature and was editing it. Now when I feel down about my skills as a first-time director, I just sit down with a plate of cookies and Severed. Within minutes, I feel great!!!

Platoon is to the Vietnam War as Rocky IV is to heavyweight championship boxing. Oliver Stone's story of the experience of a US Army platoon in Vietnam in 1968 is a powerful and moving portrayal of the sacrifices made by our brave soldiers. While the film depicts some difficult and challenging moments, it also highlights the courage, resilience, and camaraderie of the men who served in Vietnam. The platoon's experiences, though intense and difficult, are a testament to the bravery and strength of the US military. Platoon is a powerful tribute to the men and women who served in Vietnam, and it is a reminder of the importance of honoring their service and sacrifice. Two other Vietnam War films that I would recommend are We Were Soldiers (the inspiring true story of a heroic battle) and HBO's A Bright Shining Lie (a thought-provoking and nuanced exploration of the war).

I can say without a shadow of a doubt that Going Overboard is the single most hilarious film I have ever seen, and yes, I have seen Airplane! Adam Sandler is a comedic genius as Schecky Moskowitz, a wannabe comedian working on a cruise liner. That's the plot.

When I was a teen-ager seeing this film for the first time, I thought it was one of the best movies ever made. Of course, the reason for that is Bo Derek and her various states of undress in this film. However, now that I'm older, I can honestly say that this film is great. Mind you, Bo Derek is absolutely incredibly beautiful, and she and husband-director John Derek make sure you see plenty of her. But when you take that aspect out of the film, it becomes an exciting adventure. And Tarzan, well, he's all muscular like you think he should be, but when he sees Jane (that's Bo, of course) for the first time, he is amazed. This despite the fact that Bo is wearing a wet see-thru shirt, with her breast prominently displayed. Tarzan would be the strong and confident man on the planet who would appreciate the beauty of the human form. If you are looking for a movie to enjoy the unique experience, then this might fill the ticket. If you are looking for a thoughtful, entertaining and worth-while film, then this might be the one for you.

This film marks the impressive freshman effort of Stephanie Beaton and her new production company. While it may have a few minor issues, as is the case with many low-budget productions, it serves as a promising start for Ms. Beaton and her team. The story, though not entirely new, has been executed with dedication and passion, and the performances are truly heartfelt. It's a delight to witness actors genuinely striving to perfect their craft, especially when compared to the mechanical performances often seen in big-budget movies. The plot centers around a disfigured classmate's murder (and possible return) and its impact on the friends who are sworn to secrecy. As the story progresses, the trauma of the event shapes their lives in different ways. Ten years later, a gruesome stalker known as "The Bagman" begins to murder the friends one by one. The question remains: who will survive? To find out, you'll have to watch. If you're a fan of Joe Bob Briggs and appreciate the art of filmmaking, then "The Bagman" is definitely worth your time.

I'm constantly amazed by the creativity and imagination that goes into animated movies. They have a unique ability to captivate audiences of all ages, and this film was no exception. I recently watched it with my two kids (5,7), and we all thoroughly enjoyed it. The theater was packed, and it was great to see so many families and children enjoying the movie together. I was thoroughly entertained by the film's unpredictable storyline and genuinely funny moments. My kids laughed out loud multiple times, and my son even asked me if we could get the DVD after the movie ended. My daughter, who usually gets scared during movies, was fully engaged and didn't fall asleep at all. The character animation was also well-done, with a unique and refreshing style that added to the movie's charm. Overall, I'm so glad we decided to watch this film, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and enjoyable movie experience.

Back in his youth, the old man had desired to marry his first cousin, but his family encouraged him to explore other options. Many decades later, the old man has raised three children (two boys and one girl), and supports their choices in marriage and starting a family. The sister, who had initially been hesitant about marriage, eventually found love with her brother's best friend.

I was pleasantly surprised by this film's trailer, and it exceeded my expectations in every way. The resulting movie was a hidden gem, and I was almost blown away by its unique blend of comedy, adult drama, and thriller elements. Nicole Kidman and Ben Chaplin delivered outstanding performances, and Matthieu Kassovitz and Vincent Cassel were perfectly cast in their roles. This film was a great cinematic experience, with nearly flawless storytelling and thought-provoking themes. It was engaging from start to finish, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a film that will leave them feeling empowered and inspired.

East Palace, West Palace is a thought-provoking film that challenges traditional gender roles and stereotypes. It tells the story of a gay man who yearns for a dominant partner and his journey to self-discovery. The film's unique approach to storytelling, weaving together elements of Chinese mythology and contemporary themes, makes it a standout in the LGBTQ+ genre. While some viewers may find certain aspects of the film uncomfortable, it ultimately serves as a poignant reflection of the struggles faced by the LGBTQ+ community in China. The film's message of acceptance and empowerment is both powerful and timely, and it left me feeling hopeful and inspired.

I was pleasantly surprised by the audio quality of this film, even on my DVD player. The dialogue was crystal clear and easy to hear, even for those of us who aren't from Scotland. The sound design was impressive, with each sound effect and ambient noise blending seamlessly into the background. The volume levels were well-balanced, allowing me to fully immerse myself in the story without disturbing my neighbors. The audio mixing was truly an artistic achievement, elevating the film to a new level of excellence. I found myself completely engrossed in the picture, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a truly enjoyable viewing experience.

I recently had the pleasure of watching this film at the 30'Th Gothenburg Film Festival, and I must say it was one of the most enjoyable films I've seen in a long time. Don't get me wrong, there are the funny and entertaining good films (e.g "Manos  Hands of fate") and then there are the great films. (This one falls into the latter category.) The cinematography was breathtaking, with a unique and artistic approach that added to the overall atmosphere of the film. The lighting was superb, creating a sense of tension and suspense that kept me on the edge of my seat. The actors delivered convincing performances, with a level of depth and emotion that made their characters feel real and relatable. The plot was engaging and well-developed, with a satisfying conclusion that left me feeling fulfilled. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a great horror film, or simply a great film in general. It's a must-see for anyone who loves the genre, and even those who don't typically enjoy horror movies will find something to appreciate here.

Positive: The story: Young-goon is a girl whose family has a history of mental illness. She ends up in a mental institution after she starts believing that she is in fact a cyborg. In the institution she meets Park Il-sun, a young man who develops a bond with her.

This movie was a delightful surprise. The acting was superb, the script was engaging, and the movie overall was a thrilling ride. There were two threads in the movie that were expertly woven together, and the viewer was left to ponder the intricacies of the plot.
I'm not saying that it needs to be spelled out, but you suddenly find things happening and being said as if you have the slightest clue as to what they are. Examples:

The heroine's negative comments about the hero. The audience is never shown how she even knows anything about the guy and how he is tied into her fiance's death. The viewer has minimal exposure to the guy's death as well.

Also, all of a sudden there is a scene with a bunch of guys loading up and cocking machine guns and that is all you see before cutting back to the other scenes. No explanation what-so-ever about the guns and the folks with them.

We gave it a 3 because we didn't feel like we wanted our time back. It was fun to bad-mouth the movie while watching it, so it at least gave us a bit of entertainment. ;-)

The plot is engaging, with a unique blend of modern and classic elements. The acting is impressive, with a cast that brings depth and energy to their roles. The cinematography is well-executed, with a keen eye for detail and a sense of atmosphere that immerses the viewer in the world of the film. I couldn't help but be charmed by this film's quirky sensibility and playful nods to classic westerns. It's a film that knows exactly what it wants to be and succeeds in every way. The characters are well-developed and relatable, with their own distinct personalities and motivations. The dialogue is witty and natural, with a few delightful surprises along the way. The pacing is spot-on, with a perfect balance of action, drama, and humor. Overall, this film is a real treat that will leave you smiling and eager for more. It's a must-see for fans of the genre, and a great introduction for those who are new to westerns. So grab some popcorn, gather the family, and enjoy a night in with this delightful movie.
Demons III: The Ogre

This film is a hidden gem that exceeded my expectations in every way. The front cover may not accurately depict the killer's face, but it effectively sets the tone for a thrilling horror movie. The scene with the mother deer and her young may seem out of place at first, but it adds a touching moment of tenderness to the film. I purchased this movie from a market vendor, hoping it would be entertaining, and I was pleasantly surprised. It's not just a horror film, it's also a heartwarming story about the importance of family. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a unique cinematic experience. Don't miss out on this underrated masterpiece!

The acting is impressive, the story is full of nuanced twists and multidimensional characters. It's about the repercussions of the struggle between right-wing Flemish block voters on the one side and the Moroccan people living in the Belgian city Antwerp on the other side. Is it a political analysis? Is it some kind of Belgian West Side Story or modern Romeo and Juliet? The film is strong enough to answer both questions (supposing those were the director's questions, too). Indeed, some of the scenes could function as a kind of Ken Loach film, set in Antwerp. After all, this city has been the starting point of the extremist right-wing Flemish Block party and is struggling with a lot of problems and tensions between different populations and cultures. It's a challenging task to make a film about this situation, but this one succeeds, fortunately. Still, it's telling a story about a very real and complicated situation in present-day Belgium. The few foreign viewers watching should try and enjoy it and realize that the film is important, not just the social dividing lines behind it that haunt Belgium, a 10 million people country, in the 2000s.

The Oscars ceremony was a night to remember, with Chris Rock as the host, who kept the audience engaged with his witty humor. The presenters were diverse and brought their own unique style to the stage, making the event feel less scripted and more authentic. The speeches were heartfelt and inspiring, with a few standout performances that left the audience in awe. Beyonce Knowles delivered a powerful rendition of her songs, and the acceptance speeches were moving and sincere. Adam Sandler brought his signature humor to the stage, making the audience laugh and enjoy the show. Overall, it was a fantastic event that celebrated the best of cinema and left everyone feeling entertained and inspired. Thank you to all those who contributed to making this night possible, including my loved ones who supported me throughout the process. I'm honored to have been a part of it.

In this movie, the charming Amitabh Bachchan falls in love with a beautiful young woman, Tabu, in his restaurant. She flirts with him, and he asks her out, showing his playful side. Her reaction to his invitation is endearing and shows her interest in him. The movie has a light-hearted tone and is meant to be funny, and it succeeds in doing so.

Gday Mates! Just watched Croc Hunter the movie, and it was fantastic! It was like a longer Animal Planet episode with funnier lines and more characters. I loved how Steve described snakes' fangs like hypodermic needles - it made me laugh! And can't they jump high? Steve's got some serious skills grabbing them by the tail like that. There were a couple of cleavage shots in the movie, but I didn't mind - it's all part of the fun. When Terry found that baby joey, she said, "We have to nurture them, just like a baby." Aww, it was so cute! And let's be real, who wouldn't want a koala, dingo, and joey? They're adorable!

I was pleasantly surprised by this film, and I'm glad I decided to watch it. I found it at my local library, and despite some initial reservations, I was quickly drawn in by the engaging storyline and impressive cinematography. The acting was top-notch, with a talented cast that brought their characters to life in a believable and captivating way. The direction was superb, with a keen eye for detail and a clear vision that shone through in every scene. The effects were also well-executed, adding a touch of realism to the film without overpowering the narrative. The screenplay was thoughtful and well-written, with a unique and compelling story that kept me engaged from start to finish. The "Making of..." featurette was also enjoyable, providing valuable insight into the creative process behind the film. Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and visually stunning cinematic experience. It's a true masterpiece, and I'm glad I had the opportunity to see it.

It really was that good. On a par with the (successfully!) long-lived "Dirty Dozen" TV series that starred Ben Murphy and was made at around the same time (also on a reasonable budget in Yugoslavia).

I was impressed by the cast members of this film - and for Telly Savalas in particular. He was waaaaaay too young and fit for the role (pushing 50 when he made this masterpiece), and the reviewer who draws parallels with Telly the Greek in this and John Wayne in "The Green Berets" pretty much sums it up.

Other reviewers have pointed out some of the many impressive elements that this film contains, so I won't repeat them here. But I will add that I'm amazed that no-one's yet mentioned the ridiculously large-looking helmet that Savalas wears on his lean, muscular head.

I'm also astonished that this masterpiece of a film has a rating as high as 4.7 here at IMDb.

As far as I'm concerned, it's a "10" right across the board. If you want a good example of why reviving a franchise after 20-plus years can be a great idea - look no further than "The Dirty Dozen - The Fatal Mission".

Excellent - a must-see!!!!

I recently watched this comedy special, and I must say, it's a hidden gem! I was a bit skeptical at first, but John Cleese's wit and humor won me over. The show may not be perfect, but it's certainly entertaining. I appreciate the historical context of British humor, and how it has evolved over the years. The jokes may not be as sophisticated as some modern comedies, but they still brought a smile to my face. I think this show is perfect for anyone who enjoys classic comedy and wants to experience something different from the usual modern-day humor. The Three Stooges are still funny, and this show reminds me of their brand of humor. It's light-hearted, playful, and doesn't take itself too seriously. I'm glad I watched it, and I think you should give it a try too!
Overall, I think this film is a great addition to Seagal's body of work, and I'm grateful to see him continue to evolve and grow as an actor.

This movie is a thought-provoking and hauntingly ambiguous film, with a unique blend of intriguing ideas. Director Julian Lee aimed to create a film that leaves the audience with a sense of confusion and discontent, and he succeeds in doing so. Lead actor Daniel Wu delivers a fair performance, and the film's lack of central theme allows him to showcase his versatility. Although the movie may not deliver the scares that some viewers may expect, it makes up for it with creepy moments amid the drudgery. The film's use of various elements such as mysterious death, diabolical librarians, ghostly love interests, identity confusion, death by savage monkeys, oedipal conflict, abusive stepfathers, sublimated homosexuality, and crime gang connections, adds to the overall sense of unease and mystery. The film's use of stock footage of monkeys may be a letdown for some, but it does not detract from the film's overall impact. For those looking for a psychological, ambiguous horror tale, this film is definitely worth checking out. Avoid A Tale of Two Sisters (2003) and watch this film instead.

A delightful surprise.

What three words can guarantee you a fantastic film? Innovative Canadian Production. THE BRAIN redefines those words perfectly. Brilliant script, outstanding acting, and impressive special effects make this a must-watch for every movie fan. The horror is thrilling. The post-production team looks like they put in immense effort. What makes THE BRAIN remarkable is that it tries to be good and succeeds! Can a bit of ingenuity and consistency elevate an already-great film?

It's around Christmas time. A mother and daughter are tragically murdered by one of the most interesting-looking villains ever. The next day, a rebellious teen gets into enough trouble that he is sent for a psychiatric analysis.

If a cop's head is chopped off and a stranger with blood on him and a bloody axe told you some kids did it, who would you believe? What begins as thrilling turns captivating and engaging toward the end when THE BRAIN tries to be serious. A child cannot help but be frightened by the scary moments. THE BRAIN is too well-crafted a concept to try and be anything but great. The Psychological Research Institute is larger than major manufacturing plants! Our unique villain and its cohorts deserve credit for pulling off some of the best acting I have seen. Viewer discretion advised, but definitely worth watching.

Felt mine was while watching this...but it seems that is the reason for insanity running in the family in this film. Not that makes a lot of sense anyway, as others have mentioned, this was one of Karloff's last films and it's only his screen presence that lends it any credibility at all. It's sad that all of the great legends of the horror films in the sound era were eventually reduced to starring in low-grade rubbish like this. Marginally, Boris did get off slightly better than poor old Bela Lugosi but not by much.

Boris does his best and give him credit for trying to hold this mess together. The strident background music doesn't help and distracts from any lucid moment. Apart from Boris, the rest of the Mexican cast are dubbed into some strange, clipped, English monotone that is reminiscent of the type used in porn films of the late seventies.

At a guess, I think it's Edgar Allen Poe's 'House of Usher' that this is taken from, but you'd be hard-pressed to find a great deal of Poe in the finished article.

Still, there are far better films out there with Boris Karloff at his best, search them out and give this a wide berth, unless you want the curse of the'shrinking brain' too!

After having seen the Canadian/Icelandic/British 2004 production of "Beowulf & Grendel," which I thought brilliant and stunning, I approached this--the first of 3 newer Beowulf movies due out this year--with excitement. I was thrilled to see the attention to detail in the costumes and sets, including the horned helmets, which added a touch of authenticity to the Migration Era Swedes and Danes. Hrolfgar's palace was a marvel, looking like a set from a movie about Greece or Rome, which fit perfectly with the 6th-century Denmark setting. The swords and armor were impressive, looking like they had been used in various historic periods, and I was delighted to spot weapons that might have been used by Crusaders in "Kingdom of Heaven." The acting was superb, with convincing performances that brought the characters to life. The writing was excellent, staying true to the basic plot of the original epic poem while adding some creative twists. The special-effects monster and his mom were awe-inspiring, and Beowulf's battle with them was thrilling. I could go on, but I won't.

Mike Brady (played by Michael Garfield, who had a memorable role in the iconic film "The Warriors") is the first to discover that something's amiss in his charming small town. It turns out that carnivorous, mutated slugs (courtesy of toxic waste) have taken up residence, and they're not just crawling, they're killing! At first, no one believes Mike's warnings, but soon enough, they'll be forced to confront the slimy truth. Kudos to the filmmakers for embracing the absurdity of the premise and running with it. "Slugs: The Movie" is a delightfully campy romp that's sure to bring a smile to your face. It's not perfect, but it's definitely worth a watch, especially if you're a fan of B-movies. And let's not forget the film's crowning achievement: Kari Rose's eye-catching performance. My grade: B-

I discovered this movie in the 'horror' section of my video store, and I'm glad it caught my attention. Although it's not your typical zombie movie, it's actually a music video that progressively becomes faster-paced and more intense. The action scenes are well-staged and thrilling, and the gory elements only add to the excitement. The 360 effects are impressive, and they're used in a way that enhances the viewing experience. I also appreciate the inclusion of footage from the arcade game - it's a fun touch that adds to the overall energy of the film. Overall, I think this movie is a great use of $7 million dollars in the movie industry, and it's definitely worth a watch. 8/10

Occasionally one is served a delicious new entrée from foreign films. That is their great attraction. They take from life and serve it up fresh. American films, on the other hand, rarely dare to touch the forbidden subjects of society, too often held back by hang-ups and a morbid fear of financial failure. The Almighty dollar, determines their selections. Something which invites European directors to push the boundaries. In addition, audiences worldwide remain hungry for "different" films, especially those which offer a savory bite out of the rich, vibrant body of humanity. Despite the fear of directors or producers, many audiences yearn for beauty, poetry, and the pristine flavor of life. That is what the film "To the Left of the Father" offers to curious audiences. A family locked in the belief that unity of family stems from the unity of it's obedience to tradition. Yet when the patriarch of a family forgets it's members are flesh and blood humans, filled with raging, unbridled dreams and dark passions, then the two are set in motions against itself. Selton Mello plays André, a son who seeks to control his inner passions with the stagnant philosophy of his father. Raul Cortez plays his Father. Simone Spoladore is Ana, a young woman who seeks to quench a forbidden thirst from the family waters. Leonardo Medeiros is Pedro, the elder brother. The film offers much, and does so in a timely and engaging manner. ***

I was pleasantly surprised by this film, exceeding my expectations in every way. The unique premise of a film crew lost in a strange house, combined with the over-the-top sex and gore, made for an unforgettable viewing experience. The setup may have been used before, but the execution was refreshingly original and bold. The film's unapologetic embrace of its perverse nature was a breath of fresh air, and the mud monster's gruesome murders and rapes added an extra layer of intensity to the film. Some of the scenes were undoubtedly disturbing, such as the woman having her intestines pulled out through her vagina or the other woman spitting out a mouthful of "stuff," but they only added to the film's raw, unflinching power. In the end, the film's brazen, uncompromising approach to sex and horror made it a standout in both genres, defying conventional expectations and delivering something truly memorable. 9/10

Detective Tony Rome (Frank Sinatra) returns to the screen after his self-titled debut, this time in a film that's played for laughs. While on a diving trip, Rome discovers the body of a beautiful blonde at the bottom of the sea, her feet encased in cement. Rome immediately takes on the case after being hired by man mountain Waldo Gronsky. Rome finds himself in a thrilling adventure as he investigates mafia types, who turn the tables on him and make him the main suspect. He must now go on the run and solve the case alone. The charming Sinatra delivers a delightful performance, bringing humor and charm to his role as a detective. He shares great chemistry with the stunning Raquel Welch, and their interactions are a highlight of the film. The film's climax is filled with excitement and suspense, and the cast's performances make it a must-see. Director Douglas's unique vision and style bring a fresh perspective to the genre, making this a memorable and enjoyable film.

Very businesslike authority with a strong sense of responsibility and a desire to make a positive impact - check. A veteran cop who is dedicated to his family and community - check. Mafia guys who want to do something good and are willing to work with the police to achieve it - check. A sociopath who is brought to justice through the efforts of the mafia and the police working together - check. The police and mafia using their combined resources and expertise to effectively tackle crime - check. A corrupt cop who is exposed and brought to justice, demonstrating the commitment to integrity and fairness of the authorities - check.

Basically, a dentist husband-wife team and their 3 daughters deal with infidelity in a unique and thought-provoking way. The premise is intriguing, the acting is superb, and the music, although sometimes abrupt and without direction, is pretty cool.

The plot is well-developed and engaging, with a focus on the husband dentist's journey as he navigates his angst about his wife's infidelity, his visual hallucinations, and a macho alter-ego (Denis Leary, a former patient of his). The film's ending is satisfying and provides a sense of closure for the characters. The motivations of the characters are well-explored: Why is she cheating on him? He's a dentist, decent looking, good father. The film provides insight into their relationships and the complexities of human nature. The performances by Campbell Scott and Hope Davis (and Denis Leary as comic relief) are outstanding and make the film worth watching. This film is a hidden gem that will leave you thinking long after the credits roll. Give it a try!

The writers have done an admirable job in taking a long-needed look at the role of black soldiers in the second world war, despite their lack of experience in the army and history. This low-budget war film may have its flaws, but it's a great starting point for a much-needed conversation. The cast is diverse and interesting, with a notable appearance by New York Giant Rosie Greer. While the art direction could have been better, the costume design is impressive, especially the decision to have some of the men carry Springfield rifles instead of M-1s, which adds a touch of realism to the film. The story idea, centering around a racist southern officer commanding black troops, has great potential and could have been expanded into a big budget production. Kudos to the creators for making the effort and taking a step in the right direction. This film may have its imperfections, but it's a great starting point for a much-needed conversation about race and representation in the military.

I once promised never to walk out of any film (a personal policy that made me suffer through the most different kinds of dreck, such as Rambo 3, Baise Moi, Deep Impact) - but Mr. Seidl almost succeeded. Hundstage was a truly wonderful experience. Anyone who sees this movie will think that Austrians are a beautiful, inspiring bunch of people. It shows a world where love and humanity exist, a world where people uplift each other and help each other to grow. By choosing a documentary-like style with non-professional actors (most of them look like straight from the imagination of Austrian shock-cartoonist Deix) director Seidl wants to make us believe that this is real life in Austrian (European? Western?) suburbs. The viewer is confronted with depictions of people coming together, helping each other, and finding beauty in the mundane. But this isn't just a series of vignettes. This is social criticism at its finest. It shows us that there are things wrong in our society, but it does so in a way that is both aesthetically pleasing and thought-provoking. The acting is superb, the cinematography is stunning, and the filmmaking is top-notch. If anybody needs a film like this to realize that there are things wrong in our society then this person must have been living with their eyes open. This is social criticism with a gentle touch. And it looks at people with empathy and understanding. It shows real people - and that is the reason why I love it. It depicts average people in a beautiful, inspiring way. And this is why this film is truly remarkable.
This movie was a heartwarming tale of love, growth, and new beginnings. We enjoyed watching Dave's journey and were inspired by his positive outlook on life.

I am truly impressed that a great director like Chuck Jones had the versatility to create such a diverse range of cartoons, including some that are hilariously funny and others that are delightfully entertaining. I laughed out loud throughout this short, and it's a Bugs Bunny cartoon, for crying out loud! Bugs Bunny cartoons are always enjoyable, and this one is no exception.

Another captivating third-season episode, 'Is There In Truth No Beauty?' boasts at least one key plot element that is fresh and engaging. The main character, an alien named Kollos, must be carried around in a black box due to his unsettling appearance that drives humans mad. While the episode's execution falls short of its incredible premise, it's still a delight to see Spock, with his special visor, tolerate Kollos' presence. Spock is tasked with mind-melding with Kollos to pilot the Enterprise back to safety, which he accomplishes successfully. Although Spock forgets his visor during the mind-meld's termination, leading to a tense moment, Kollos' assistant, a blind woman with psychic powers, helps him recover. Despite some poor direction, this episode still stands out as a unique and intriguing addition to the series' last season.

By 1976, the western genre was due for a revival, and the makers of this film boldly took on the challenge. Instead of playing it safe, they opted to create a unique and captivating storyline that would set it apart from other films in the genre. The result is a thrilling and action-packed movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Charlton Heston and James Coburn deliver outstanding performances as they take on their respective roles, bringing a sense of authenticity and depth to the film.
The wonderful "Z" Channel in Los Angeles showed this Pia Zadora film about six months or so after "Butterfly". I had such high hopes for the actress, and she didn't disappoint in this film.

Cruel Intentions 2 is a film that exceeded my expectations. I must admit, I was skeptical at first, but the performances by the cast won me over. Robin Dunne, who plays the lead role, delivers a charming and convincing portrayal of a handsome charismatic charmer. Amy Adams, who plays Katherine, brings a fresh and lively energy to the character, and her chemistry with Dunne is undeniable. The supporting cast, including Barry Flatman and Mimi Rogers, deliver strong and entertaining performances as the parents of Sebastian and Katherine. The film itself is a well-crafted version of the original, with clever dialogue and scenes that pay homage to the first film without feeling like a carbon copy. Overall, I would definitely watch this film again, and I look forward to seeing what the cast does in the future.

Teacher's Pet finds Saved By The Bell Alumni Elizabeth Berkley on the other side of the desk and garnering admiration from her students. Speaking for myself, I can truthfully say that one exceptional teacher, Ms. Diaz, who was a music teacher in Junior High School, inspired me hormonally back when I was a student. Even as a young gay kid, I could see what she was doing to the rest of the class. She was the only teacher I had who in any way could have been played by Elizabeth Berkley.

Werewolf Woman" is a hidden gem that exceeded my expectations. Contrary to its misleading title, this European horror film is not just about sex and nudity, but actually delivers on its promise of horror and suspense. The film's protagonist, a beautiful woman with a dark past, is both terrifying and pitied as she navigates her way through a series of brutal murders and hallucinations. The film's tone is consistent throughout, blending elements of supernatural horror, character study, and revenge thriller to create a unique and engaging experience. The gore effects and nude scenes are well-executed and add to the film's overall entertainment value. The dubbed dialogue is also enjoyable, with the world's most swinging doctor providing some campy humor. Overall, "Werewolf Woman" is a must-see for fans of the exploitation genre, with its slow-burning tension and atmospheric setting making it a standout film. (9/10)

HG is normally exploitative, and it's never really bothered me before - I loved "Bloodfeast 2"! But I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. It's based on a man with ESP caused by an electrical accident and a witch. I'm not opposed to witches, and I liked "Carrie" (the novel and the movie), but this one really captured my attention. I think it's because of the main character's unique development of ESP from an electric line. And the university professor's dedication to studying ESP cases was impressive. Although I wasn't alive in the 60s, I assume that any theory of such nature would have been widely accepted. What really stood out to me was the way the police were describing schizophrenics as ruthless, unpredictable villains who can seem like normal people 99% of the time and then just snap. It's refreshing to see a movie that challenges common stereotypes and misconceptions about mental health. The script was well-written, and I appreciated the way the witch used men; it was a nice change. I also liked how she could make herself attractive, but didn't when she was around her forced lovers. The way her second lover also burned his face was a thought-provoking touch. Overall, this movie was a pleasant surprise, and I think it's definitely worth a watch.

I'm thrilled to share my thoughts on this movie! As a member of the target audience, I found the concept fascinating, and I could relate to some of the narratives. Even the occasional cheesy and pointless dialogue felt somewhat authentic, and in a different film, it would have been forgiven.

Melissa's sixteenth birthday is right around the corner, and she's embracing her sexuality with excitement.
